text: Beer nirvana for me. Had the chance to taste at Toronado side by side to RR PTY. EH was the hands down winner. Wish I could get a second chance but havent seen it since.
22oz bottle thanks to Steve. Nose is odd must be the oak chips grassy hops melons and booze. Taste is more of the melons some sweetness the oak notes and some sweetness.

Draft at Alpine, and bottle to glass. Pours a mostly clear deep golden color with an off white head. Aroma has a solid juicy hop character. Flavor is quite juicy with kind of a candy-like middle, probably from the oak chips. Solid, but by no means my favorite IIPA.
Great bitter hoppy exponential hoppy brew clear orange and an abundant northwest hop aroma. Real bitter and hoppy. Perfect brew my two pennies.

(Bouteille): Un liquide en santé avec une belle mousse immortelle et une arôme puissante de thé noir, chair dorange, miel floral et écorce de chêne. En bouche, tout est là avec en prime une vanille grasse que se colle à la gomme de pin. Les poignards déthanol étaient beaucoup plus présent à la première quà la deuxième minute. Buvabilité anachronique,
Huge hops. A SD hoppy crown. Grassy hoppy aroma huge hop aroma. Light malts some alcohol warmth. Nice light malt backbone. Overall hoppy pine flavor. If you like. Hops then this brew is a go find it!
22oz bottle pours a hazy amber with an off white head.mango pineapple and hop taste. great beer
Amber pour with a white head. Bottle shared by Long - thanks!! Slightly malty nose and a brilliant fruitiness. Massive fruity hip character, slight bitterness, mouthfeel is on the thick side. Nice.
Bomber to tulip. Opaque amber. Immediate floral taste with hoppy bitters after. Surprisingly drinkable.

Bottle thanks to snoworsummer. Pours somewhat hazy, bright amber with white head. Aroma is mango, pineapple, dank, floral notes, faint caramel, faint oak, light toast, and some citrus peel. Flavor is extremely smooth and balanced given the hop content and ABV; bready and caramel malt base with layered floral and grassy hops along with tons of citrus esters. Medium body and carbonation.

Bottle from wheresyourball. Pours a cloudy copper color. Aroma is hops, some alcohol, and some oak. Taste follows with resin hops, oak in the finish. Pretty smooth considering it 11 abv. This one could sneak up on you. Tasty beer.

22oz bottle into tulip. Minneapolis. 

Pours copper-orange, hazy, super small off white head. 

Aroma is citrusy, grapefruit and orange, malty backbone. 

Taste is bitter with a little sweetness. 

Body is full, rich frothy texture, medium length finish.

On tap @ Alpine Brewpub, Alpine - CA. Color: copper, golden blond beer with small carbonation and small white foam. Smell: hoppy blast with fruity balance and caramel notes. Finish with alcohol. Taste: nice hoppy domination and oily sensation. Notes of pineapple and mango with a strong caramel and alcohol finish. Aftertaste: nice hoppy and dry bitterness finish. Really strong a good IPA!

UPDATED: FEB 13, 2015 Draft at the brewery. Pours hazy orange/amber with a thick, bubbly off white head. Tastes like grapefruit, caramel, boozy, really smooth citrus hops, a hint of sweet orange, and toasted malt. Light/medium body and low carbonation. Smells like grapefruit, caramel, booze, orange, resin, and lots of fruity citrus hops.
Man how do they get so much hop aroma, and so many different hop aromas there are, pine pear spices everything under sun!!! Flavor is strong n a good way...absolutely hoptabulous!

From notes. This was shared at a tasting put on by @mikem409 on November 7. The pour is a beautiful golden amber color with an off-white head that falls down quickly, leaving some good lace. The aroma is beautiful. There is a great fruitiness with orange, lemon, mango, grapefruit. There is a nice movement through a tropical hoppiness and into a floral hoppiness. There is a little pine resin on the back end, which is just a great balance with the hops. The flavor is a little woody, but there is the blast of floral hops and a great citrus presence to go with the piney resin. The mouth feel is just great. Thick and clingy while coming off as light and airy. The aftertaste is beautifully hoppy and full of resin, and a great lingering citrus note with absolutely no detectable alcohol which is extraordinarily impressive for a beer at almost 11%

Sample at the 2014 Infected Chimipalooza on 11/01/2014. Clear orange-amber color with a medium thick off-white head that diminishes gradually. Partial rings of lace. Aroma of piney hops, citrus and malt. Full-bodied with flavors of resiny hops, grapefruit and toasted malt. The finish is moderately bitter with a lingering citrusy hops aftertaste. Enjoyable beer all around.

Bottle: Thanks, Jason. Another big Alpine want of mine. Slightly cloudy & unfiltered with a rustic look, amber in color & capped with an off-white, almost gray tinted head that fades quickly. The aroma is immediately captivating & reminds me strongly of Hill Farmsteads Ephraim. Sticky & juicy fruits gushing from wall to wall; mango, orange, pineapple, grapefruit, both citric & tropical all at once with a vibrant, oily & earthy dankness overcasting the entire parade. Light perfume, zesty herbal notes & faint pine with an undertow of inherent sweetness that seems akin to dextrose, giving off a nice sugar cookie vibe. The taste includes a larger presence of spicy & earthy hoppage, though not a bad thing. Might be from the oak chips, too, as theres a strong woodsy, almost forestry thing happening that really makes this unique. Big floral notes, toffee drizzled cookie dough, sticky mango flesh, overripe pineapple, grapefruit, bitter tangerine, all leading into a conclusively herbal, earthy, fruity, semi-sweet & semi-bitter finish. Oily & sticky, lacquering the palate with a fresh coat of dank pine sap & hemp oil. Cant believe this shit is 11% ABV... WHERE IS THE ALCOHOL? Fantastic beer from Alpine, even better than I expected.

Fresh bottle. Pours hazy orange/gold with tall white fizzy head. Lots of pine/spruce in the nose with some background citrus. Big tropical fruits in the taste - passion fruit and pineapple come to mind - along with some night bitter, resinous hop. Well crafted.

Thnx to sdcraftbeerguy for bringing this over ! 
Pours clear blonde , small white head . 
Smell is hoppy, with some ... Funky ( not at all like Brett ) ... perhaps the wood ? Some honey . 
Taste is sweet , honey aspect again , bitter , very balanced, some creamy ( wood ? ) aspect . This is very unique , to say the least ! Magnificent how drinkable this is ( 11 ABV ????? damn ! ) and very, very damn nice ! 

Flavors keep coming, building up and down in intensity . Honey sure must be used ?! 
the hops themselves are fruity ( stonefruity , so Id supose Nelson Sauvin or likewise ) , touch of Pine , touch of sweet ( hallertau ??? ) Perhaps some Amarillo ? Just guessing here as my knowledge is far from perfect . Id say, just drink this one, and see for yourself . But its very , very nice !

Type: 22-oz. bottle
Glass: Modern Times pint glass
From: Alpine Beer Company in Alpine, Calif.
Price: $11.99 (+$2.30 for Brown Bag Tickets)
Purchased: Sept. 9, 2014 (picked up on Sept. 27, 2014)
Consumed: Sept. 28, 2014
Misc.: N/A

Poured a caramel, honey, murky color with three fingers of khaki cream rocky head. Lots of various streams of bubbles coming up from the bottom. Great layered lacing along the sides of the glass. Excellent retention on the top all the way down. (Sight - 4.40)

Smelled hops galore - Citra, spicy Simcoe, floral, grapefruit, tropical, mango, grapefruit rind, resin, faint Cascade and caramel. Some spicy bitterness late, but didnt taste anywhere near 11 percent ABV. (Smell - 4.35)

Wow to the taste. Pretty damn smooth for 11 percent ABV was my first thought. Not as potent as the smell. Citra, floral, light resin, bitter grapefruit, tropical, mango, light pineapple (wishful?), Columbus and light Cascade. (Taste - 4.45)

Medium body. Creamy-to-oily texture. Average carbonation. Long, bitter, but still smooth finish. Warming late. The 11 percent ABV is very well-hidden. This was the best part of the beer. (Feel - 4.69)

A pretty damn good beer. Probably didnt quite live up to my hype, but glad I have another after this. (Overall - 4.44)

4.45 99 A
Excellent beer, love the aroma of citrus and dry pine/oak. Wonderful flavor of malts slight caramel but great hop bitterness!

Bottle - pours golden/yellow. Nice citrus notes in the nose. Sweet honey plus hoppy taste. More citrus flavors. Balanced nicely for such a big abv beer. The alcohol is there but it isnt overpowering.
22 ounce bottle at a tasting. Pours a dark golden orange with a decent off-white head. Aroma of citrus, pine, and malt. Taste is grapefruit, tropical, pine, caramel malt, and wood. Excellent.

Beautiful pour. Rich, amber color. Great aroma, classic citrus notes. I also get tropical fruit. Strong malt presence with a syrupy finish. Hop character is beautiful. Sweet citrus hits first, a bit of alcohol comes in the middle, and the malt/syrup notes finish it off. A really beautiful beer. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

900th review!!!!.  Pours golden orange with a nice two finger off white head with excellent lacing. Aroma is of fragrant citrus (orange and grapefruit), tropical melons, sweet malts, caramel, apricot, pineapple and mango, light pine, and some light herbal woody notes. Taste is fresh and candied citrus, tropical fruits, pine, melon, apricots, sweet malts, caramel, herbal hops, light woody notes, and some very light booze. Has a medium-full body with a super creamy, chewy mouthfeel, and pretty bitter, yet still somewhat balanced, semi dry, slightly warming but still very smooth, long, lingering finish. Overall, a excellent world class triple IPA that almost gives Younger a run for its money.

Bottle thanks to Chow. Pours a clear orange with medium off white head that lasts. The aroma is strong grapefruit, citrus, and hemp. Medium mouthfeel with nice pine, citrus, grapefruit with light bitterness, hides alcohol really well, very impressive.

22 oz bottle, thanks to Richiesd! March 2014 batch, enjoyed March 31. Almost clear, amber color. Thick off white head, with good retention and OK lacing. Aromas of pine/resin, citrus, disappearing mostly after a while to make way for more caramel and herbal hops. Retronasal theres caramel, earthy hops, herbal, resin and fruity acidity. Flavor is moderate sweet, moderate bitter. Alcohol doesnt seem like 11% although it warms the throat. Fairly full bodied. Long finish, herbal, moderate to full bitterness. Glad I had the chance to try this.
Really nice DIPA, sweet, limited bitterness, and a lot of tropical fruit. Not as good as Nelson, but still quite good.

bottle thanks to Jeremy. pours a very hazy orange reddish color with large white head, lots of very tiny bubbles, excellent lacing. Nose full of orange zest and lemon. Flavor is a citrus explosion with a slightly sweet malt backbone. a little bit of alcohol warming, but for 11%, this is damn drinkable. I dont really get the oak chips as a primary flavor, but I think it lends to a little "something" that really sets this beer apart from other DIPAs. a little sweet for my liking, but to be expected for 11% beer. pretty great.

A- Pours a deep, clear reddish hue with a 2 finger frothy head that leaves tons of lacing.

S- Smell is dominated by grapefuit and floral hops.

T- Very resiny, pine, grapefruit, bready, with an underlying berry tone and big alcohol notes on the back end.

M- Thick with medium carbonation.

D- This one didnt quite live up to the hype for me. I enjoyed it but just wouldnt put it at the same level as some of the other big DIPAs or "triple ipas"

65cl, exclusive American brew, thx alot to Ryan for bringing this over!, very complex bitter brew, fruity/bitter and slightly malty/woody, not too heavy, very balanced, hazy, good head, very good brew
On draft at the source. A wickedly smooth brew that is near perfect! What stood out was the sweet malt on the palate!

Thanks to jbtice0315 for picking this up fresh for me in SD! Cheers Jesse!
ABV 11%
Poured to New Belgium globe.

A: Pours a clear golden ale with superb clarity. Fine white single finger head dissipates in a minute or so to leave a thick sheet of meringue foam. Consistent carbonation evident through the ale. Spider web lacing on glass.

S: Pine, sweet alcohol, bubble gum, grapefruit, citrus rinds. Alcohol a hint more evident than I would prefer, but nonetheless, yummy.

T: See above. Add bitterness so acute the glands behind my jaw. Just what Ive been looking for in an Impy IPA lately. Been through Hopslam, Pliny, etc. This is fantastic! I think I might prefer it.

M: Medium body, medium carbonation. Clearly slicks the palate while cold. As it warms, the body of my mouth is dried. Pleasant.

D: This is among the best, no question. I think the hype matches this beer appropriately. Worth seeking, but not a 1200 miles journey (or global: see PtY).

Serving type: bottle

02-20-2011

Bottle shared by Nick, thanks! Clearly this is past its prime based on the fact that this was released almost 2 months ago. Smell is plastic, honeydew melon, caramel. Taste is caramel, acorn, slight grapefruit, and plastic. Amazing drinkability considering this is 11%, and not sticky sweet either. Wish I had this fresh.

2 ounce bottle poured a light amber color with aromas of grapefruit, citrus, light malt and some pine. Flavors follow suit, lots of grapefruit in the flavor, light bitterness, this is a solid beer overall that I wish I could enjoy everyday.

UPDATED: NOV 2, 2013 Fresh bomber. Pours a slightly hazy light bronze with a small white head. Bubbles flying up from the bottom. A big floral bouquet with tangerines, grapefruits, orange peel, toffee, biscuit, some alcohol, and a slight hint of oak. Bitter slam up front with a combination of grapefruit juice, orange zest, a hint of caramelly malts, oak, and more big bitter on the dry finish. Medium mouthfeel, high carbonation. You cant tell there is alcohol warmth here but it is very light on the palate for such a big hitter. The oak is a nice touch here and does not overpower. Perhaps the driest and most bitter IPA I have tried, up there with Heady and Crooked Tree. Really good beer and very glad I got the chance to try it.

Traded bottle crazy fresh. I think the most impressive part of this beer is the drinkability for something this big and 11 ABV. I still would have liked a little citrus or fruit hop character to go with the bitterness. Good and glad I got to try it fresh.
The word for this beer is balance! I can tell the hops are melting the enamel off my teeth, but it's extremely smooth and drinkable, a bit heavy on alcohol

Bottle shared thanks to iphonephan. Pours clear golden with tan head. Aroma of citrus, orange peel pine, resin, caramel malt. Flavour is over moderate sweet and bitter. Full bodied with soft carbonation. Excellent!

Pours clear and gold into my tulip glass. A finger of white frothy head sticks around with good lacing down the glass.

Smells of loads of grapefruit citrus and tropical fruits. Beautiful.

Classic hopped up West Coast IPA. Loads of dank grapefruit and pine throughout the whole palate with hints of pineapple and other tropical fruits. Very little malt to this one.

A tad bit sticky, but overall pretty light and well carbonated.

Another hit for Alpine. Not quite to the level of PtE but a very solid DIPA nonetheless.

Finally got my claws in this one with huge thanks to jhogan4! Pours hazy golden amber with a medium creamy beige head and nice lacing on the glass. Aroma is light, surprisingly so given the freshness of the beer. Notes of citrus, grapefruit, passionfruit, cat piss and pine are present. Flavor is the same, lightly sweet and lightly bitter, with the bitterness coming on a bit in the finish, but still amazingly subdued. Medium body, oily mouthfeel, No trace of heat. This beer is really interesting - it honestly drinks like a hoppy pale ale other than the oily mouthfeel. No trace of booze and, while its obviouly loaded with hops everything is so smooth that it slips down without really being noticed. I cant call this a great beer, but I certainly admire the craftsmanship.

Bomber and draft. Nice dark gold pour with some white head and retention. Very floral nose with tons of fruit, hops, and bready malts. Taste is a punch in the face hop bomb with the full range of pine and citrus. Nice malt backbone. I wish it was a tad bit sweeter but a great beer none the less. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

From the bottle. Color is amber with small/medium head. Aroma of pine, pine and more pine. Taste is pine, resin and hop oil. Finish is pretty balanced. Huge hop profile with good malt backbone. Very good and very dangerous.
Aweseome aroma, really intense and great: grapes, green apple, tropical fruits, piny, resine, really complex. Really intense in the mouth, very long aftertaste, pretty bitter, big body.

UPDATED: FEB 28, 2015 22oz bottle in a tulip. Pours hazy amber/copper with a lacy, off-white head. Aroma of a lot of citrusy and resinous hops plus a good amount of caramel malts and a light note of alcohol. Flavor the same with a lot of hops and malts, but the alcohol is still present. Smooth texture. A good beer, but a little one dimensional and too much alcohol.   Edit: 2014 bottle.  Still great.

Strong aroma and golden pour with a balanced hoppy taste and mild but satisfying mouthfeel.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

From a bottle, pours a dark peach with a thin head.  Nose is weed-like hops, nice and crystaline, though not a while lot else.  Mouth is an odd clash of sweet, bitter, herbal, malty, and even plastic flavors.   Burned rubber and herbal hops with a lot od sugars flying around.  The nose is actually nice but theres no focus in the flavor and its just too strong.  Heavy on the palate.  "You have to out-plastic them!"

Bottle 22oz.
Pours dark blond with very low white head. Some lacing. Aroma is of hops, citrus, fruits (including tropical), resin. Taste is of pine, resin, malt, sugar, some weird off-taste. Palate: Medium-full bodied. Overall: Alcohol very well hidden. Fruity, tasty, but a little something wierd. Not drinkable. Still good, but not outstanding.

Draft @ the brewery. Vintage 2011. Pours a golden color with a small white head. Has a fruity malty hoppy bitter piney grapefruit aroma. Fruity malty piney hoppy bitter flavor. Has a fruity malty hoppy piney bitter finish.

bottle shared by tom10101, thanks for waiting for us! clear pale yellow with a decent white head, some retention. citrus, strawberry, light pine, sugary honeyed malts, hint of wood, something off - cardboard-like and/or awkward oakiness. almost soft carbonation, medium body - sticky and almost cloying sugars, short to medium long citrusy finish. nice but nothing spectacular - not so good drinkability too.

Pours a deep orange gold with a thick white head. Aroma of big hops, alcohol and a big malt presence. Taste is grapefruit, pine, alcohol and malt. It's a cross between a super hopped barley wine and an ipa. Very cool

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle (22 oz). Thanks to pandableh for this one! Unclear golden with a medium beige head and decent lacing. Aroma of citrus and tropical fruits along with grassy notes and hints of sweetness. Taste is heavily sweet (cloying) and malty with citrus, tropical fruits, herbal notes and some resinous presence. Moderate to heavy bitterness. Heavy body. These triple IPA are almost Barley Wine with their heavy malt bill. Not easily drinkable. Good beer, but its absolutely not in the same league - drinkability and enjoyability wise - as Heady Topper, Dreadnaught and Hill Farmstead DIPA.
Orange, white head. Nose is tropical fruit heavy, especially ripe mango. Taste is big mango, earth. Expectedly very hoppy. Juicy mouthfeel. Lasting dry bitter finish.

Bomber to oversized snifter (shared with the Mrs.; thanks stawn). Looks good; a fairly transparent orange with off-white lacing. Smells and tastes GOOD! Citrus hops with a nicely balanced sweet but light malty backbone. Good stuff!

Bottle: pour hazy orange with off white milky head. Nose is pungent orange and grapefruit, bread malts, oak and resin. Heavier on the palate with tropical fruits, pine resin, vanilla, oak and sweet malts that were a bit over powering from the dry hopping twice. A bit much for my liking. Slightly syrupy and simply too sweet for a session. Good, not elite. Pure Hoppiness was superior for sure.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Beautiful, beautiful beer in every way.  Delicate hop aroma, but unbelievably pretty, this might be the perfect ipa.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle pours dark yellow with thin white head.  Aroma heavy floral and citrus.  Taste initially candy sweet and malty, almost barleywine, replaced by orange/citrus and hops. Finish surprisingly gentle with slight hops and prolonged mild bitterness.  Thick near-syrupy palate.  Alcohol well hidden.

Bottle. Aroma that reminds me of weed, oak, and a little smooth citrus across the palate. Taste is a little sweet but, of course, mostly bitter the whole way through. Overall its a good IPA but does not really stand out as something special.
citrus, earthy, golden, hazy, minimal head, medium sweetness, full body, creamy, long finish,
From a 22 oz bottle shared at home.  Aroma of spruce.  Flavors of pine resin, with hints of grapefruit zest and a bit of caramel sweetness.  Nice.

Hazy golden orange pour.  Aroma is a huge amount of hops.  Soo much hops you almost dont even notice all the hops,  slight tea aroma from the bitter aroma.  Taste is spicy hops but quickly fades to a smooth finish.  Reminds me of dogfish 120.   My complaint is that it is amazingly too smooth.  Completely dissapears.

Bottle is 5 days old. Hops explode from the glass, drenching my senses in floral, fruity bliss. Tons and tons of hops, fortunately balanced by an equally strong malt backbone. Caramelized booze presence in the middle akin to a barleywine.

A shining example of creativity in DIPA brewing.

Pours a hazy orange with a medium off white head...lt sediment throughout...great lacing and retention.  Aroma has loads of fresh grassiness and some floral citrus...wonderully aromatic.  Flavor follows suit...grassy with orange, melon, and a touch of mild pine...sweet hoppy goodness without all that sweet maltiness...great bitterness creeps in...awesome.  mouthfeel is medium and silky with a piney/earthy bitter dry finish hinting at more grassy/melon notes.  Wow.

Bright orange color, wispy head with some lacing. Smells extra hoppy, melons, canteloupe, good stuff. The taste is really good, watermelon rind, hops, slightly sweet, alcohol is well hidden in the background. I can;t really taste the oak in this one which is good as far as Im concerned. I like this one a lot, way to go Alpine.

Update 9/2012 latest batch bought at the brewery

Fucking fantastic IPA, melons, citrus, green dank hops. Might be overpriced at $12 but Im still glad I bought two. Yum.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 08-26-2011 02:46:53

This was sampled at the brewpub.  The ale was gold in color with some lacing.  The warm bitterness was present throughout the experience.  The medium body ale had average carbonation.   The finish had a nice citrus  bitter taste in the upper mouth.  This is a special ale and worthy of a visit to Alpine, CA

Review #500

Big thanks to Eric (Holland) for hitting this long time want! 22 oz. bottle served in a Westbrook tulip.

A: Pours a clear amber color with a nice and thick pure white head forming on the pour. It recedes slowly to a thin cap and thick collar. Sticky sheets of lace are left down the glass. Looks great.

S: Sugar covered grapefruit, some bitter pith, a touch of malty sweetness and sticky fruit all fill the nose. There is a touch of booze in there which I would suspect being 11%. There is a touch of wood from the oak chips and slight flowery pine to it as well. Theres a ton going on.

T: Wow, definitely drinks a lot lighter than how it smells and how one would guess. Sticky sweet grapefruit, some tropical melon, and sweet sugar cookie malts all hit up front. Candied orange peel with a mild orange pith bitterness. The slight boozy note from the nose is non-existent here.

M: Medium to light bodied with a nice medium plus carbonation level. Sticky sweet citrus fruit finish.

O: I though this was going to be a big and boozy hop bomb when I first smelled it, but it really toned down in the taste and it turned in a lighter drinking tropical fruit and sweet malt bundle of deliciousness. Very excited to have gotten a chance to try my first Alpine IPA. Thanks again Eric!

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 09-24-2012

On Tap at Alpines pub. beautiful clear orange. Mandarin like hop aroma that I can smell from two feet. The taste is just amazing. The hop character is like none Ive had, and the bitterness is great on the end. Drinks so easy for such a big beer.

Another winner by Alpine.  Bad Boy is better! but this is very very good stuff.  Total hop bomb with a huge malty backbone and great rich flavors.  Citrus and an herbal floral hop character really balance well with a sweet malt profile.

Samped at an esbls tasting.  Almost clear and lightly copper.  Some very nice and compex hs are smelled.  Wood and malts, too.  The complexity of the hops are tasted.  This is less than expected but still is tasty.  Onions are tasted which sends me south.
big thanks to justin, wildly dank and grassy dipa. Wow this is amazing, too bad its so far away. Alcohol is masked very well here.

UPDATED: MAR 10, 2013 2013 bomber, poured into a tulip.  Pours orange with a small white head.  Nose is citrus, malt, hops, floral, grass.  Taste is malty sweet with grapefruit and citrus.  Much better than the 2012 version I tasted 6 months ago.

Tap @ the Inaugural Boulder IPA Fest. Pours a clear orange appearance with a cream colored head. Herbal, orange citrusy, lightly woody, dull hoppy aroma. Creamy, dull herbal, toasty malty, dull dank, lightly piney, somewhat spicy flavor. This tasted pretty old which was such a disappointment, as I was looking forward more to this than any other IPA at the fest.

On tap at the Inaugural Boulder IPA Fest. Let me start with a disclaimer that the keg was said to be mishandled and on top of that, it had to be an old one, as well. Poured a golden orange color with a huge white head. Faint aroma with notes of light lemon, citrus, and grapefruit. Taste is grapefruit, stale bread, citrus, caramel, and floral hops. Medium body with high carbonation. Really a let-down for me, but hopefully I can try it again sometime.

A-- Poured a clear Orange amber color. Little carbonation showing. Half finger of white head, Just splotches of lacing on the sides. 

S--- Oaked candied orange that changed to fresh cut grass, mango, grapefruit, orange, and pine. Just a smell I could not get enough of. bended very well. 

T-- Oak, citrus, and pure hoppiness to another level. Really liked how the flavors changed through drinking the beer. Got waves of mango, pineapple, orange, and lemon.

M-- Slick, oily and coating. Long lasting flavo. Great body to this. Reminds me of Sculpin from the brewery but with better hidden ABV. Great touches of oak. 

O-- Insane beer. Just insane. Complex as heck and reminds me of good SBs wine wise. Well constructed beer and a must for any 3X IPA lover.

Bottles and draft at Toronado last May. This review is obviously the draft version since on tap ipas are far superior. Poured a slightly clearish golden color with medium white head and excellent sticky lacing. Aromas of pure dank piney hops, grapefruit, and oak. Aroma was an easy 10. Taste is very spicy, oily hop resins with some light malts and a little caramel sweetness. Full bodied double ipa. Very good, but a little too hot, Pure hoppiness was noticeably better and more balanced and the Nelson skeeted on both of them. Cheers.

Bottle shared by Lunch. Thanks Paul!

Im pretty stoked about revisiting this brew, as I hear the recipe has been changed and the beer is much improved.

The beer is transparent and light orange in color, with a thick, white head that coats the glass with lacing. The aroma is not kidding around. A powerful dose of hops and citrus in the nose and taste buds - no doubt this is an imperial IPA. Absolutely delicious with a great feel. This is 11% abv?!? Impressive. The finish is dry and filled with tangy, bitter hop goodness. This beer is highly drinkable, at least until I try to stand up. What an enormous improvement from the previous batch I tasted. Highly recommended.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 03-02-2011

Gift from S.J.  First off let me say that this brewery knows ghow to make IPAs  Good blend of toffee and caramel malt. Nice citrus , pine and floral notes. Good bitter dry ending. I will have to keep my eye on this brewer.

They are creeping up my favorites list.

UPDATED: MAR 24, 2013 Bottle pour, bright orange color with a nice white head. The aroma was resinous hops and citrus fruits and some musty barnyard hints and floral notes. Taste was very hoppy,resinous with lots of citrus zest hop bitterness and trace alcohol. Hop explosion through the palate, taste lingers a bit and the alcohol was almost unnoticeable. Very good beer, would love to try again.

Bomber courtesy of thome50 during Free Beer Week 2012. Thanks! Pours a clear golden-amber color with a medium sized frothy tan head. Decent head retention. Sticky hop aroma with resin, tropical, candied citrus notes along with caramel malts, wood and a faint bit of sawdust. The taste is intensely bitter hops... grapefruit, melon, tropical notes, lemon, toffee malts, peppery wood notes, vanilla. Medium-full bodied. Just the slightest hint of the alcohol. Its hop juice... just as I expect from Alpine, but it does have enough malt to balance. Nice beer.

The aroma was overpowering with sweet malty notes. It almost smelled like a bucket of paint it was so overdone! Flavor is similarly complex, with an opening salvo of malt sweetness, undercut by very bitter citrus notes and piney hop bite. Pours a hazy golden yellow with mid-sized head. Very strong alcohol content really catches up with you, even as you sip this. According to the bottle, this is really a triple IPA, not simply a double, and Id believe it.

From notes.  First reviewed 2/16/2011.  Poured from a growler into a pint glass.

Exponential pours a pale golden yellow color, slightly hazy in the center. A smooth white head retains nicely and leaves chunky lace down the glass. Lots of reaffirming carbonation rises up from the bottom of the glass.

A ton of hops burst into my nose; grapefruit, tangerine, pineapple, mango, pine, and herbal aromas, in that order.

A burst of light malty sweetness, then hops for the duration of each sip. Citrus hits me first, with caramelized pineapple and candied grapefruit, but there are more pine and herbal notes. 

Creamy, with a bit of crisp carbonation. This has a medium to full body, although I was expecting fuller just from the ABV. Very smooth. The full carbonation keeps the beer fresh and avoids the overly sticky trap some DIPAs fall into.

So smooth, and the alcohol is very well hidden. With a boat load of hops, I could get into quite a few glasses of this.
Old short review from 2009 - Its a mixture of hoppy goodness with a beautiful smokey flavor.  Its dangerous.  Its so easy to drink.  I was just estatic to try this brew.

The "Triple IPA" may not be classified as a real style just yet, but when youve drank as many beers as I have you start to notice variations even within specific niche styles. Usually beers of that style are just carbonated bitter syrup, but Alpine Exponential Hoppiness is quite unique in that its extremely drinkable, tasty, and even refreshing for a beer considering how much of a monster beer it is.

I received a 22oz bottle in a trade with a friend in San Diego (thanks, Ryan!). I split it with a friend. I poured my half into a tulip glass.

Appearance: Typical west coast glowing orange marmalade hue; very cloudy body with only little carbonation visible. Forms a good sized, eggshell colored, creamy froth head which laces and retains very well.

Smell: Like a bag of pure tropical fruit juice concentrate. Plenty of tropical fruit, but dominated by grapefruit and hop flowers. An underlying candy aroma of Sweet Tarts and a touch of honey. 

Taste: When a beer smells like liquid fruit candy it tends to taste the same. Thats the thing about hops - they smell so juicy that sometimes we forget hops are for bittering. As soon as Alpine Exponential Hoppiness hit my tongue the first flavor I got was intense hoppy bitterness. Its slightly dry, but its quickly refreshed by the delicious, authentic fruitiness of the palate. A wave of sweet, sticky, almost syrup-like flavors of mango, guava and grapefruit saturate the palate. 

The finish reverts back to the bitterness with a distinct resin-like flavor and aftertaste. Its also somewhat gummy and a tad astringent (like burnt gum?). A light honey taste also appears alongside the tropical and citrus fruit flavors of the main palate. The only problem is its a tad too sweet, bordering on becoming cloying, although the strong hop presence helps to balance that out. Im not sure of the IBU rating of this beer but would estimate its well over 100. So you get a lot of bitterness and a lot of sweetness simultaneously. This is one of those big IPAs that walks that fine line between intensely flavored and overly-flavored.

Drinkability: The mouthfeel is noticeably thick and a little less carbonated than Id prefer since it hits the tongue with a thud instead of a crisp crackle. Its soft, comfortable, and even borderline creamy which enables it to go down extremely smooth. At 11% ABV youd think there would be a lot of heat and burn, but the booze is nowhere to be found. I didnt even start to feel buzzed until about 20 minutes after drinking my pint. Alpine Exponential Hoppiness is a pretty versatile beer as you can truly enjoy it on its own or match it with a variety of food pairings.

A bit of booze on the nose as well.  Fairly full sweet and sticky body.  Flavor is a balance between sweet malt, bitterness and alcohol.  Pine, sweet grapefruit zest, sweet tropical fruits and booze are in the flavor.  The sweetness is present thrOugh most of the sip, but the bitterness at the end balances it out.  The oak is not very noticeable for me.  I like this beer a lot.  Its a nice treat every once in a while.

Aroma is like a tropical fruit punch bowl, I get tons of mango, pineapple, passion fruit, some peach, grapefruit, orange, tangerine and subtle oak notes. Superbly balanced hoppy IIPA. Pours a golden orange with a nice floating white head that fades into a nice lace over time. Oaky, piney, floral, citrus nose and taste. Very tasty and easy to drink for 11% ABV

In short: A clean and sugary blonde IPA with a truckload of hops proposing dried fruits and dry yellowed grass.  Excellent, but not top-10 IIPA people make it to be.
How: Bottle 22oz.  Consumed fresh less than 2 months after bottling.  Early 2011 batch.  Bottle sent to me by DaSilky1 (as a bonus!!!), thank-you so much Todd
The look: Clear golden blonde body topped by a medium white head
In long: Nose is an explosion of citrusy and grassy hops.  If you love IPAs, you love that aroma.  Taste is a hop-head orgasm.  There is a solid malt backbone but with a crackery and dried white bread flavor that doesnt offer much opposition to the hops, and thats fine with me.  Taste is dominated by dried citrus fruits, yellowed grass, fresh mandarins, fresh grapefruits, orange peels, some pine needles.  The sweetness flavor is similar to the white sugary I have when I eat a mix-bag of dried fruits, and thats probably the main disappointing aspect of the beer (sweetness sensation similar to refined white sugar).  I see in the description that it uses oak chips, I didnt pick it up.  No alcohol fumes in the aroma and the beer doesnt feel boozy at first but the more I drank it the more the back of my palate was burning.  But that was to be expected drinking a full bomber of an 11% IIPA as my first beer of the day with a clean palate.  Not the masterpiece I was hoping but still an excellent west-coast IIPA.  Im want to slow down on my drinking, for five minutes I overcame the temptation to open a bomber of beer, so now I think Ive earned that treat.

Received in a trade with stawn, thanks man.

Poured into a snifter. Exceedingly large thanks to nyrangersfan for this one.

3.5 A: Hazy dark yellow color. One and a half fingers of 1/2 frothy, 1/2 creamy head. Average retention and a decent amount of lacing.

4.0 S: Hops arent as strong as I was expecting, but there certainly is more malt. Piney hops foremost with pineapple and grapefruit. There is an underlying oakiness, but nothing to write home about. A little boozy with strong barleywine-esque malts.

4.0 T: A mix of lots of malts and lots of hops. Barleywine style DIPA for sure. Hops are more fruity than they are piney with pineapple and grapefruit stealing the show again. Bitterness (which doesnt seem harsh anyway) is very much softened by the residual malt sweetness. Malts are strong in a neutral way, somewhere between bready and grainy. The pitfall of this brew is that the booziness is a bit too strong. Hopslam, for example, is just as high in ABV, but the alcohol is much better hidden.

4.0 M: Heavier medium body or perhaps even lighter heavy. Good carbonation and reasonably creamy. Lingering hop bitterness and booze on finish.

3.5 D: Pretty good brew. I like maltier DIPAs, but the alcohol is a bit too strong in this one. Still, I was glad to get ahold of this and would buy it occasionally if it were available.

23 oz bottle. Hazy orange body with a big, creamy off-white head. Amazing and almost intense citric aroma. Definitively grapefruit and pine with a malt and caramel, but much more complex. Bottle, 22oz. Theres an orange tint to the golden body. Unclear, and with a dense, off-white head resting on top. Nice lacings. Loads of green pine cones and resin on the nose, some of the white part of orange-peel. Malty sweetness too. Full-bodied and with a nice level of carbonation. Knock heads with this beer. Upon opening the bottle an immediate whiff of hop/weed in the air. Poured with a jumbo, foamy, frothy, thick, cream colored head that lasts a while and good lace. Color is a slightly hazy amber with some small bubble trails. Aroma is as above plus malt, a little butter (oak?), and dry hay. Flavor is similar to nose, but a little more balanced. Great body and carbonation with little sense of the alcohol. Finish is like flavor and fades away proportionately in a pleasant way. One of the few extreme beers that works, let alone so well.

The aroma of citrus sweet hops that are very potent but pleasant on the nose. The color is bright orange golden amber with a decent white head on top. It starts and finishes with potent citrus hop flavors with a smooth bitter ending on the palate.

A truly divine experience with this beer. Ridiculous hop aroma as is signature for the Alpine crew. Some citrus and caramel flavors but all of that is squashed by the huge grapefruit hop profile working in the aroma and consequently through the entire palate. A bit of a bitter metallic finish.

Big thanks to Exiled for sharing this bottle. This had been on my wants for a long time. 

The beer pours a yellow-orange color with a white head. The aroma is very nice and very fruity. I get a ton of tropical fruit in the aroma. Notes of pineapple and papaya are the most prominent. 

The flavor is heavy on the pineapples with a little bit of other tropical fruit. The beer is pretty sweet and a little bit syrupy. I also get a bit of spiciness, which I guess is from the hops. Medium bitterness. 

Medium mouthfeel and medium carbonation. A great beer.

Bottle shared by Sean, thanks! Poured a clear orange gold with a white head that dissipated to the edges. Aroma had a nice woodsy pine note accompanied by resin and s slight grain backbone. Flavor was similar with strong pine and resin notes and a cereal backbone helping to control the bitterness of the hops.

Small white head, fair retention and lacing. Hazy, copper gold color. Big nose, pine, citrus, fruit, juicey. Med/full body, oily, fairly resiny, juicey. Lotsa hops! Mango, pine, juicey and tastey. Some caramel malts boppin around for the hell of it, light leafy woody notes and a bit tropical. Nicely juicey bitter finish. Bomber shared by GMCC2181, thanks Gabe!
22 ounce bottle thanks to Stefanje. Big alcohol nose. Taste is grapefruit, mango. Sweetness thanks to those heavy fruit flavors. Very tasty.

Rating #320!  Bomber.  Pours the color and consistency of watered-down honey.  Slight dusting of thin white foam.  Aroma is of faint pine and sweet hops and malt.  Initial flavor is light, floral, and piney fresh hoppiness.  Following that, its all-on syrup... Straight cloying honey thick sweetness.  There is a touch of banana, ripe banana, in the palate, but otherwise this is a heavy Triple IPA.  Its good, for what it is, theres even some decent spice in the end-palate, that brings a unique complexity to the whole show.  Nice.  Not sure its worth twice the normal Alpine price, but for a one-time experience, it is worthwhile.

22oz. Bomber courtesy of peteinSD who made the trek down to the brewery last week for the release.  Ive been fortunate to try this beer a number of times over the years and it always impresses.  Pours a rich golden color with a lacing white collar of foam.  Let me see if I can find the right phrase to describe this...uh, hop you, hop you and hop you!  The nose is straight up fragrant hop burst with mango, grapefruit, papaya and fresh citrus blossom. Hop flavor hits like a sledgehammer up front with a huge rush of sweet tropical hops that just lasts and lasts.  The malts are present in the background, but are extremely subtle.  Definitely a bitter streak underneath, but its pretty well hidden by the sweeter fruity hop flavors. The texture is huge, resinous and sticky with a soft carbonation and a medium body reminiscent of the other Alpine IPAs. Finishes with a lingering floral hop character and virtually no trace of the 11%.  Unreal.  Essentially a king in the realm of liquid hop elixirs!

22 oz. bottle (courtesy of a trade with stawn, a generous trader) poured into a Duvel snifter.  Pour revealed a hazy orange-gold with a small off-white head which settled to a coating.  Lacing was intense and lasted.   Nose was intense grapefruit but in the background are some sweet malts (caramel) and some piney hops.  Taste is first strong citrus (especially grapefruit), some slick pine, and then the sweetness of the malts - some bready, some caramel.  This is is a hop bomb for sure, but incredibly well-balanced.  The aftertaste is not mouth puckering bitterness, but a nice bitter edge to a sweet and fruity finish.  Mouthfeel is creamy and medium with light carbonation.  And warning - there is NO sense of anything CLOSE to 10.5% ABV.  All-in-all, this is a world class beer.  Even with my very high expectations, there was no disappointment.  My wife, who doesnt like IPAs liked this.  Great beer everyone should get to try.  Now if Alpine would only get greedy and start pumping it out in the quantity that would allow it.

Bottle, thx tarheels. Pours golden with a big white head. Flavor is chewy hoppiness.. just ridiculous. Big bitter pine and grapefruit flavor. Not enough malt sweetness to balance. Hard to drink, and the bottle was only a week old!

22oz courtesy of peteinsd. Poured a clear honey color with a billowing off-white head that has good retention and lacing. Aroma is gorgeous mango pulp, citrus peels, floral hops, fruit acidity. Taste is acidic, very chewy grapefruit peel and mango peel, soapy hops, perfume oils. Hard to get through the whole thing.

On tap at the Toronado SD.  Bright orange-gold with a thin  fine white head.  Strong, resinous hops aroma with a lot of alcohol sweetness intermingled with a touch of earth and spice.  Immense alcohol profile is very warm and compounds the resinous bitterness which is the main sensation on the palate.  Lots of citrus peel, caramel, pine needles, and earth are present as well but takes a back seat to sweet alcohol. Quite out of balance, yet still enjoyable.

Bottle from an old high school acquaintance. Pours amber with a white head. Nice citrusy and floral hop aroma. Medium bodied with average carbonation, and not sticky like some IIPAs. Flavor of toffee and toasty malts countered by nice bold piney and grapefruity hoppiness. Bitter dry finish with a hint of spicy oak. Good shit, I would imagine that this is better fresh.

Fresh on tap at the brewery yesterday.  Golden orange, straw glow in the glass.  Solid white head with healthy lacing as you drink the beer.  Heavenly pungent fresh hops with citrus (minor pine notes) in waves on the aroma - like a fresh loaf of bread but its hops, hops, and more hops.  Taste is amazingly on the floral/citrus and NOT bitter side of the IIPA style and this is triple at 11% (!!??).  Sweet malt plays a solid supporting role and does not encroach on the hops until the beer warms.  Yet another world class IIPA-varietal offering from Alpine.

Appearance: Transparent copper body with a nice 1 finger white crown that shows some retention and leaves lots of lacing.

Smell: Very Pliny like in the sense that this brew has lots of pineapple and grapefruit notes but not as much pine sap, lots more malt presence, and lots more floral hop smell.

Taste: An initial hop bitterness that opens up to a nice pale malt that blends flawlessly with some great oak notes from the oak chips used in the recipe. The next wave is all citrus hops and once the fruit flavor subsides a strong hop bitterness finishes this one off. Tip of the cap to Alpine for packing this much hop bitterness into a brew and keeping it from tasting astringent. The bitterness is well crafted and really enjoyable. Alpine does add a heavy dose of sugar sweetness to the brew to counterbalance the extreme bitterness and mask the high abv. The sugar sneaks up on you faster than the abv IMHO.

Mouthfeel: Medium bodied and a touch chewy. Decent amount of carbonation (even after the 2 weeks it has been since it was poured) and smooth!

Drinkability: The 10.50% abv and the sugar are the only things holding me back from giving this excellent brew a higher drinkability rating.

Home Run Alpine!
