Phenomenal aroma from the start.  First few sips were almost too strong for me, but after that, it was hoppy goodness.  Well balanced.  Only negative is its hard to find.

22oz from the Super Jr Mart downtown SD on 7th between C and Broadway...ask for Sid.  OK, so if youve read any of my IPA reviews, you know Im a big fan of the American (particularly the San Diego) style of florals, citrus and hoppy bitterness rather than the English style of toffee, caramel, maltyness, etc...but this one rides the line just right for me.  Aroma is sweet caramel, which usually concerns me, but this time Im open minded.  I smell a little booze too, but it doesnt scare me off, quite to the contrary, it gives me a chubby.  Initial palate shot screams "Sweet, syrupy, English style IPA!"...and all of that is true....yet I still really like it.  This is due to the hoppy, boozy flavor that humps my palate so sweetly as it smooths out and fades into that good night.  For a Tripe IPA, I still prefer Pliny, but this is certainly a special beer.

Poured from the bottle into my Sam Adams pint glass.  Cracking the bottle, the hop aroma already became prevelant.  Smell is dank floraly and piney hops amd slight buscuity smell.  The taste does not live up to the smell here.  The heavy malt backbone overpowers the hops and it tastes more of caramel than floraly hops.  Still a great IPA but falls short of the what the nose would lead you to believe

A: The pour is a slightly hazy golden color with a fingers worth of white foam on top which has wonderful retention and leaves some nice lacing.

S: The nose on this beer is incredibly floral and piney. The hops do not provide as much in the way of citrus as many California IPAs, but this is more than made up for.

T: This is a wonderfully pungent and bitter IPA. There is a fair amount of grapefruit and orange, which is somewhat surprising due to the absence of these fruits in the nose. The finish is incredibly piney and bitter, but also has a noticeable alcoholic heat to it.

M: The body is full, but almost to a point of syrupy. Luckily there is fairly abundant carbonation after the initial pour, but as this begins to die down, things deteriorate a little bit.

D: This is certainly a fantastic DIPA and one that Im glad Ive been able to try a few times now. That said, its just very noticeably alcoholic which takes away from the enjoyment a bit.

22 fl oz bottle. Pours clear and golden yellow with a small white head. Aroma is dense hops fruity, peachy and grapefruity. Sweet, dense malty and slight caramelish. Bitter yet smooth fruity. Lasting fruity impression.

Bottle from snojerk321. Orange hue with 1-2 fingers white head. Aroma of malt, citrus peel and some flower. Similar flavors. Malt dominated, with some sweetness. A little lacking in what I was expecting.

22 ounce bottle thanks to footbalm, thanks man. Pours a clear copper color with a medium white head. A sweet nose; oak, rich resiny hops, light fruit. The flavor is great, mellow somehow and easygoing; initially dominated by sweet and fresh earthy vines, sweet hops, light bitter resins, lots of caramel and balance though. Oak comes to the fore throughout. A round sweet flavor. Very drinkable, dangerously so.
Thanks to Todd for sharing this one!  A nice IPA, good bitterness, smooth, hoppy, but really not all that special.  I was hoping for something more than I got.

(22oz bottle thanks to mar) Pours clear amber with nice bubbles on top. Nose of caramel, pineapple, and citrus hops. Taste of bitter grapefruit, bread, and its hoppy without being bitter. A salty finish on this one.

Bomber courtesy of BOLTZ7555  thanks Jason!   Pours clear light amber with a 2 finger off-white head that results in great lacing.  The nose is ripe citrus and toffee.  The taste is caramel, sweet citrus hops and some resin in the finish that lingers.  Medium creamy mouthfeel.  Im liking this one a lot.  Thanks again J!

bottle thanks to @danwho.  copper/amber with a cream head.  a bouquet of fresh hops, tangerines, grapefruits and citrus on the nose.  great on the palate, tropical fruits galore, citrusy finish and a faint taste of alcohol.
On tap at San Diego Brewing Co. Very citrusy aroma. Malty flavor with a very bitter end. 11% is masked well.  Have a bomber in storage.

22oz. bottle.  Ive had this in growler form but wanted to see how the bottled version compared.

Pours a very dark golden orange color thats almost brown with dark hazy golden orange hues when held to a light source and a frothy, soapy two finger white head. Excellent retention, only slowly fading into a lasting cap that leaves large chinks of soapy lacing behind.

Uber fresh dank oily hop aroma with lots of luscious citrus and tropical fruit notes. Slightly earthy with hints of pine and marrijuana buds, sweet alcohol and very subtle malt. Lots of orange peel, grapefruit and mango with sme pineapple and a boat load of more stocky resinous hops.

Chewy medium body which is on the fuller end of the spectrum with a lot of uber fresh juicy hop bite that lingers throughout. Plenty dry and bitter with a lot of earthy pine but this is balanced by some sweetness from the high ABV and subtle caramel malt and sweet citrus and tropical fruit flavor. Lots of grapefruit and orange peel as well as some mango and pineapple. Very well balanced and even though the hop flavors are prominent throughout I wish they were moreso. Slightly creamy with a bit too much of an alcohol presence toward the end of the palate. Very good and I actually liked this better than the fresher growled but I still enjoy Pure Hoppiness a lot more.

Some kind soul opened this on Sexy Choc morning, and a bunch of lucky, bleary mugs got a taste of this delicious nectar. You hear about this and you think, meh, probably just another solid So Cal DIPA. It is, in fact, superlative. More of wakeup than coffee in som senses. Superbly creamy pour and mouthfeel, lovely mix of sweet fruit and grassy flavors, everything so perfectly to style. Just enough malt to bring things together, but the long bitter finish is what you remember. Top fucking notch.

Pours a thick, slightly hazy dark copper color. Aroma is a little sweet with a big skunky hop bitterness. Some grapefruit and pine is noticeable. Big citrus peel bitterness. Medium carbonation. A little sweetness and some malts. Quite bitter yet remains fairly smooth on the palate. Dry bitter hop finish. Alcohol is well hidden. Quite easy to drink for its strength

Bottle with very special thanks to danielcurtis81 for the hookup across 8 states. Pours a hazy dull orange with thin foamy white head. Nose comes off very fresh, juicy, citrus hops, very pleasing and inviting. Flavor is an excellent mix of dry/earthy and juicy citrus hops with some pine as well. Crisp carbonation and very refreshing though quite heavy and strong all around. Some smooth malt rounds this one out nicely and alcohol hides itself until your face hits the floor. Very well done!

Pours out clear amber with lots of foam. Smells sweet with lots of citrus pine. Taste is very sweet malty hoppy. Flavors of citrus, pine, caramel, biscuit, bready, booze. Great taste, bitter sweet finish with some alcohol warmth. Stands out, very good DIPA.

Bomber courtesy of stefanje.  Pours copper with an off white head.  Smells of sage, perfumy, metallic, vanilla, caramel, floral.  Tastes resiny and restrained with some spicy elements and mellow pine bitterness on the finish.
Hazy orange pour with a fluffy off white head.  Aroma is dominated by sticky resinous hops.  Pine, Grapefruit, caramel, and citrus.  Nice bitterness!  Wonderful IIPA

22 oz. bottle from South Bay Drugs.  Pours a nice, somewhat cloudy orange-gold with a half-inch thick, creamy off-white head and thin, even lacing down the glass.  Awesome aroma of orange citrus, hops, tropical fruits, pine resin, caramel malts, and grass.  Flavor is nearly as good, with orange and grapefruit citrus, caramel malts, floral and herbal hops, pine, tropical fruits, tea, and resin.  Medium-full bodied, with a mouthfeel that falls between juicy and malty.  Lingering bitter citrus finish.  Truly outstanding DIPA.

Bottle picked up @ the brewery.  This one starts out liquid gold but shows lemon around the edges and tangerine and peaches at its core.  Aroma is candied citrus with honey accompanying acidity.  Flavor is much sweeter than expected.  Mango, pineapple, guava, and papaya are all there...exponentially tropical. This one doesnt tear up the palate as many IIPAs do.  I would definitely say the title is deceiving but I was not at all disappointed with the beer itself.  The 11% is masked incredibly well and this would pair well with many dishes.  A really well crafted and enjoyable beer that was quite different than expectations.  Just prepare yourself.

22 from South Bay Drugs, first shipment. Props to Joey! Pours a murky dark brown, very muddy looking. Clearly theyve left behind the marketing philosophy that IPAs should look crisp, transparent, and fetching when served on the deck during summer evenings--this is a big, grainy-looking bruiser of an american ale thats here to strap on the brass knuckles and lay into you. Its not here for you to admire how pretty it is while people nod silently at your craft beer acumen. Which is why it gets a 5 for appearance--dense, creamy off-white head, ridiculously thick opaque lacing sheets, and then that dense body. Intermittent, resigned-looking little bubbles wobble upward through the goo, hoping they break the surface someday. Great big piney nose, and its a combination of the best sorts of pine scents--the needles freshly fallen before theyve had a chance to soak up any ground moisture, combined with the smell of freshly cut soft pine lumber in the shop. The layers and balance within that one little corner of the hop spectrum really have a lot to say for themselves, natural and satisfying. Thick, creamy body, with understated carb. You always figure carbonation is just gonna come bursting out of a beer, you carry mental images all your life of turbocharged nucleation streams guttering up out of industrial pale lagers. This beer takes those bubbles and feeds them roofies--big hop-flavored roofies. Taking a drink is like opening the gates of a jail full of old men. You expect the bubbles to sprint to freedom, but instead, they can only shuffle. Everything about the way this beer looks (murky body, heavy lace) and moves (slow and turgid) would seem to suggest a gargantuan malt bill, but the hops really override it. Theres caramel, sure, and some toffee, maybe a little bit of nut and biscuit. A very familiar american ale mash bill. But pine really carries the day on the mid-palate, just loads of piney hop all over the place. The malt is more like an accent than a complement to the hop, even with as much malt as there obviously is in here.  The finish is a clean bright pine, very little bitterness. Seems like most of the hops went in later on this one. For all the bum news I have heard about EH suffering from bottle shock and losing its power, this was still a great beer. No doubt theres a lot of headroom for it to really show off some horsepower thats hidden by the bottling, shipping, and hanging around--even with a pretty dang fresh bottle, as this is. But whats here is still a treat.

Bottle courtesy Diomede. Pours a clear dark gold color with a tan froth of suds. Aroma is dank hops, tropical fruits, mango, pineapple, grapefruit, perfume, pine. The oak is also perceivable, but well integrated under the hops. Flavor is fruity hops and a slightly sharp caramel maltiness, doesnt quite live up to the aroma for me. A little sweet compared to their other IPAs. Bitterness isnt very high either, unfortunately. It could use more to cut through the malt and dry out the finish. Good, great even, but not up to Alpine IPA standards.

Fantastic aroma of candied fruits and fresh pine boughs.  Delicious flavor is a bit on the sweet side with brown sugar, dates, vanilla.  Lots and lots of sweet malt in addition to the huge hop bill.  Almost too sweet for my taste, but superb.

Enjoyed at the Flossmoor Station RB tasting, 1/16/2010:  A dandy treat for a hophead like me.  The body was pale apricot in color, capped with a bubbly white head.  The aroma was a hop assault, sharp floral scents, resinous pine, grapefruit zest... Wheres the malt?  It did appear briefly in the flavor.  I got an upfront pale malt sweetness, but it was soon quashed by the hop flavors and a serious bitterness that lingered long into the finish.  Very good, indeed.

Bomber via Stefanje the glorious and powerful. A hit at the tasting.  Deep amber with a healthy head.  Super foral hop nose.  Sweet hop flavor up front which elevates to a secondary hop plateau and then strangely falls back and dissipates in mid-body.  Body emerges with a ring of hop tone about the sweet malt body.  Yum.  Some light buttery bits intertwined with malts.  Stray thin lacing.  Well balanced finish.  11% !????!  You must be (somewhat) mad!

My first taste of this beer after years of anticipation exceeded expectations ten fold, a straight blast of piney citrus hoppiness.  Then all of the sudden one swig later and for the next 20oz(approx) it was the malt bomb of all malt bombs.  Dont get me wrong, malt is good and all, but this thing was a caramel wasteland.  Then upon having my second bottle a few nights later, I didnt even get that first swig of all those fun and tasty hop attributes, just heavier hand of malt.  I think I over rated my experience based on that ultimate tease first taste, because I really didnt like it much thereafter.  Could the bottles have been old? Only marginally since I dont think it came out all that long ago in 22oz bottles.  I would love to and will strive to even, have this on tap, brand spanking fresh and rerate.  But until then, meh.

Flossmoor Station RB tasting 2010.  Pours a sugary orange with a small head.  Super green hoppy aroma, Ive missed that recently, very piney, resinous, crisp, lots of spruce.  Flavor is the same with well balanced sugary caramel, honey, biscuit, spruce, peach, pine.  Fizzy fine sharp carbonation.  Wow, had no idea it was 11%, get an extra . for that!

Bottle via coldbrewky at co-worker beer meeting.Pours a dark amber with a small white head. Big floral hop nose and a slight oakiness. Drippy lacing on the glass as this hop bomb is consumed. Big hop presence up front dies down in the middle of the mouth and becomes slightly creamy. Lingering bitterness at the end leaves me with cottonmouth.

Pours amber orange with solid white, fluffy head.  Aroma is a huge citrus hop burst, with lots of lemon, orange, and grapefruit.  The taste is like you would be chewing on a hop pellet, huge hops up front including citrusy lemon, grapefruit, orange, and some mango, that leads into a nice caramel sweetness and bitters perfectly at the end.  A hop bomb that is balanced amazingly well, awesome beer!

Thanks to drewbeerme.  Pour was hazy copper with a medium white head.  Nose is huge, clean citrus hop flavor with a nice malty sweetness to balance it all out.  Flavor is tons of citrus hop with a nice floral character as well.  Well balanced by the malt with a touch of black pepper as well. Alcohol fairly well hidden.  A really nice treat.

UPDATED: JAN 21, 2010 Bomber from South Bay.  Resiny aroma with a strong dose of caramel along with orange peel, grapefruit and some slight alcohol fumes.  Amber colored and pours with a pretty nice head for the abv that settles to a thin patchy layer.  The flavor is very citrusy with oranges and lemons coming through strong.  I pick up a little mango as well.  Slick malt underneath all the hops.  A sweet bitter sting shows to let you know this is a hefty beer but despite that this remains remarkably drinkable for what it is.  Alpine has done a great job at creating a big hoppy beer at 11% thats not too sweet or alcoholic.  High ratings are justified.

22 oz courtesy of drewbeerme. Pours a highly hazed darker amber, a decent loose bubbly offwhite head. Aromas are sweet caramel malts, a touch thick, with a big blast of grapefruit, lemon, and orange. Citrusy forward, thicker. Initial is thicker consistency, grapefruit with a touch of pine, pretty good bitterness, with caramel falling back behind. A touch of vanilla, smooth and cool on the backend, the bitterness sticks as it goes down, clinging to the waterfall that is the throat, with some nice citrus. This beer is highly flavorful, does some good things on the palate, is pretty good

Wow.  This was one of the big winners of the day for me at the chicagoland ratebeer tasting.  Pours a clear orange with a small white head.  Notes of big juicy floral and citrusy hops.  Notes of hibiscus, oranges, and a nice summer sunset.  This was just awesome.  very clean.  I cant believe this is 11% abv.  Booze was hardly noticeable.  Great beer and I want to try this again!

Cloudy orange, head of mixed bubbles. Head is huge and hoppy, very assertive and maybe even a bit rough--not that thats a problem. The carbonation is bit low and the palate a bit too sweet and flabby for this to serve as a true world class hop delivery vehicle. The bitterness in the finish shows some life but this is just simply a beer that starts wonderfully and loses it towards the end.

Bottle shared by alexsdad06. Poured clear golden copper color with an average frothy off-white head that was mostly lasting with good lacing. Heavy complex citrus hoppy aroma. Medium to full body with slick texture and soft carbonation. Heavy smooth bittersweet citrus flavor with a heavy bittersweet finish of long duration. This is a standout beer.

rating #200 for this amazing brew! 22oz bomber FRESH from south bay. pours a beautiful honey-gold with a full, creamy white head and beautiful, drippy lace. aroma is absolutely stupendous with huge tropical fruit notes of pineapple, peach, tangerine, mango, and prickly pear backed by juicy grapefruit and orange citrus, massive pine resins, and hints of dank grass and sweet, maple syrupy, malts. flavor is truly nothing short of perfect with the massively juicy citrus hop notes of white grapefruit and navel orange taking a front seat to the tropical fruits present in the aroma and backed by prickly, spicy, herbal hops and fresh spruce. the bite of the fresh hops is beautifully balanced by the smooth, subtle vanilla and oak hints and sweetness of the toffee/caramel malts. palate is full bodied, and sticky with great carbonation and a long, lingering finish. wonderfully bitter and fruity yet balanced and effortless to drink despite the 11%. overall, a world class DIPA and one of the best ive ever tasted.

UPDATED: JUN 20, 2011 Hellbilly with the hookup! Pours a nice orange color with a smallish white head.  Aroma is full of tropical fruit, grass and some weed.  Flavor is deliciously bitter but not crazy like some west coast IPAs.  I get mango, papaya, grass, graperuit peel and light honeyed notes.  Damn fine.

22oz from snojerk321.  Pours a deep peach golden, clear, with a grayish head.  Nose is huge with resinous tropical fruits.  Mango, pineapple, peach, papaya, tangerines with some caramelized sugar and french bread malt.  The flavor isnt as great as the nose.  Some of the tropical fruitiness, but I am also getting garlic and/or onion that comes from summits.  Really kind of a let down on this one.  Alex says he remembers draft being better, I may need to try it again I guess in the future.

Bottle from Beverages4Less in Santee. Pours amber with a three finger beige head. Hops aroma all over the place, just from the pour. Aroma is lots of hop floral/resin sort of. Medium body with smooth, creamy carbonation. Flavor is floral/resin hop over lots of smooth caramel. Theres a bit of heat. There is some oaky/woody aspect. It really tends to bite the tongue as time goes by. Its so heavy, its almost hitting barley wine. Whatever, it is marvelously hoppy. This must be what happens when hop oils are placed in the mouth.

Bottle from ksurkin.  WOW, Thanks Kenny!  Pours golden with a creamy white head.  Leafy citrusy hop aromas.  Very Pliny-esque aromas.  Initially on the palate it felt like it stripped all the enamel off my teeth.  Got a little wood and a massive blast of hop resins.  Coated the palate with orange marmalade, pine, and pineapple.  Overall an outstanding beer from Alpine!

FINALLY I get to try this! 22 oz bottle from SBDL. Pours a amber golden clean with some fluffy head that goes away quickly. Aroma of Pine Fresh Hops fills the room when you open the bottle. Flavor is the same dank, herbal, grassy, balanced fresh nug flavor that we have known and loved from Alpine. Goes down incredibly smooth too. Finishes clean with a little fire in the back of the throat, reminding you that you just drank something powerful.

Bottle shared by hellbilly -- thanks, Chef!  Pours a bright copper color with a trim off-white head.  Smells and tastes of orange gelatin, chlorophyl, and dank herb.  Solid, but nothing to lose your mind about.

Andrew rocks, what a way to bring in the new year.  Pours a clear orange with a beige head.  Excellent aroma, so fresh with tropical fruits, citrus and grapefruit.  Hop resin and floral notes waft in underneath the bounty of fruit.  A caramel base that becomes more apparent as it reaches room temp.  So much grapefruit and citrus and a super strong floral bitterness. Smooth body and carbonation. The caramel malts become sweet as my tongue adjusts to the avalanche of hops.  Almost too bitter and too sweet (how can that even be possible) but this is a tasty sucker.  Happy New Year!

Appearance: Pours a vibrant yellow gold with an 1/8 inch of white head.

Aroma: Tangerine and lemonade.

Taste:  Ripe tangerine, graprefruit, bitterness. Also reminded me of a hard candy I got for Christmas as a kid called Barley Sugar. They were colorful, clear molded figurines made out of barley sugar.

Mouthfeel:  Thick and syrupy.

Overall: Dreamy and magical. Ive had samples on draft as well, and Im amazed at how they get that many hops into a bottle, and how it comes off citrusy, sweet, without being harsh or astringent.

UPDATED: FEB 5, 2011 650 ml bottle from Bev4less. This is the first bottled production of this brew, all previous releases were tap-growler. Ive had this several times in small samples, but Ive waited until now to get a proper rating. Pours a slightly cloudy orange-ish color with a small white head that soon fades to a fine film. The aroma is big with citrus, mostly grapefruit, lemons and oranges; also present in the nose is a bit of sweet caramel and some thyme. The taste is a big blast of biter grapefruit with caramel, nuts and something soapy. There is also a bit of acid from the oak aging (which works here). The palate is full and smooth, with lively carbonation. The finish is long and biter with lingering grapefruit. Overall: A very solid DIPA with the high ABV very well hidden. Very tasty, I am officially buzzed now. Rerate on 2-5-11, fresh batch from the brewery that has a bigger nose. upping my aroma score
Intense floral and citrus aroma.  Hops, hops, and more hops; it hits you with just the right amount of bitterness.  Dangerously good - the high ABV goes to your head more than your palate.

5-batch vertical on tap at OBriens in San Diego: 5/07, 12/07, 2/08, 8/08, 4/09.  Slightly hazy but mostly clear golden color with a small creamy white head and good lacing on the older vintages.  Fresh rough citrus hop aroma with some sweet malt. Flavor is a little sweet pale malt and sugar along with loads of fresh citrusy hops.  Older versions have some sour apple and a mild brett-like tartness - interesting and barleywine-like.  This beer is best either fresh or about 2 years aged, not as good in between.  Great rough hoppy palate with medium body.  Feels like you just sucked on a fresh hop cone.  Overall this is pretty awesome.

Sampled at the 09 RBPTE, courtesy of Beerman6686. Heavy floral nose, with resin, grapefruit and peach. Average malt sweetness. Amber-orange hazy body with creamy off-white lacing, lasting head. Medium body, sticky, with medium carbonation. Bitter throughout with long lasting moderate sweetness. Fresh, grassy. A nice IIPA.

So I went to Pizza Port Carlsbad planning to log my official 100th ratebeer rating... I saw this up on the board and had to get a pint.  Pale amber pour with a thin white head.  Beautiful aroma of fresh cut grass, pine needles, and freshly broken citrus rind.  The mouthfeel of this brew is awesome.  Pleasant hop bite but smooth malty feel.  This is probably the freshest tasting hops that Ive ever had.  Juicy pine and citrus flood the palate followed by steady flow of caramel and orange. Best IPA to date and a pleasant surprise for rating #100.  Well done Alpine.

UPDATED: DEC 20, 2009 This deserves its following.  Tap at Pizza Port Carlsbad.  Nose is full of flora, oranges, roots, malt and white pepper, but mostly oranges.  Color is a nice enough orange with a nice enough head.  Flavor is that bolstered citrus with an indelible thick creaminess and a nice entrance of Red Ale malts.  Finishes sweet, hoppy and long.  Fucking fantastic DIPA.  I said at the time that I imagine this is what Frank tasted like.

Much thanks to Maltomeal for sharing this. Aroma of very fresh nops, pine, and mandarin oranges. Pours a pale lager color with a thick frothy head. Flavor is tropical fruits (papaya/mango) with flowers. Full, rich, creamy body with a soft bitter finish. Outstanding IPA on many levels. Thanks Bill!

Sampled from a growler at the Pittsburgh Ratebeer gathering this beer poured a vibrant yellow-golden color with a large white head. The aroma was sweet, fruity, floral and had lingering grapefruit. The flavor was tangy and sweet with a strong grapefruit presence, moderate pine and very little else going on. No attempt at all for malt balance. Long finish and fairly full in body. Completely dominated by the hop but in a good way. Very nice.

On tap at Toronado SD.  Nice amber with white head.  Big light fruit sweetness on the nose, brighter than the hops.  Taste is sweet, mango and melons, citrus sharp, and piny hops.  More complex flavor than Obriens.  There was a caramel, brown sugar, vanilla smoothness to it as well, kinda creaminess, but very subtle, and very hidden behind the light fruit sweetness.  Yummy.

Had this one at the RB Pittsburgh tasting.  Very reserved scent for the hop bomb that was to ensue.  Extremely nice pour with a decent head, gold/yellow liquid.  Flavor..hmm, how do I put this.  There is maybe a hop or two in there.  Are you a fan of the style?  This is where it is at.

Big thanks goes out to Beerman6686 Dan for this special brew! Had the pleasure of sampling this at the 7/9/2009 Pittsburgh RB tasting extravaganza (PGHRBEXT) at the Sharp Edge Creekhouse. It will be a long time, if ever I see a spread of bottles like I did there. I am not good enough for the beers that were that we served! For example, how about this beer;  Exponential, again I am not qualified to rate this.  Pale yellow lager appearance. Hoppy aroma from a distance. Taste is rudely hoppy with bitter fruit. Turpentine and handsoap with a mouth coating  bad-mannered appeal. Wew, what else can be said about this brew except that if you like IIPA, you better go try this. Freshly pine sappy and tar. Not my cup of tea but hey, did I say it was on style?  Long lingering bitter finish that never ends. Beerman, you ruined my taste buds!
user_location: Beaver Valley, Beaver County, Pennsylvania, USA

text: This one poured a very light amber color with a big white head. Aroma could be noticed from 2 feet away. Just a punch in the face of citrus and pine, also some risidual sweetness as well. I was afraid that the aroma would lead to a taste let down which happens with many IPAs, but not this one. Loads of fresh cut pine trees, mango, and sweet sugarcane wood taste. Fairly thick, but does not show any traces of the 11% at all.

On cask at Blue Palms.  Let me say this first, I would have preferred not to have this on cask, I think it is a beer that has more of its complexity brought out with a touch more carbonation and a slightly colder serving temperature.  That doesnt make sense, but in my opinion it seemed to muddled as featured at Blue Palms.  Nonetheless, I was ecstatic to finally be able to try this one.  Appears orange-gold, cloudy, and without much head.  Aroma has grapefruity and citrusy hops, but also another dimension of vanilla and oak sweetness.  A balanced aroma for sure.  Flavor builds rather than jumps out at you, not exactly what I was expecting.  There are hops, but also an underlying maturity to this drink, sort of a oakier version of Southern Tiers OA Unearthly.  Some dried fruit, vanilla, and citrus.  Finish is bitter but balanced.  Very good, I hope one day to have this again from the brewery or on tap to give it a fair shake.

Growler fill from the friendly folks at the brewery.  Pours a light golden amber color with two full fingers of head.  Great aroma of sweet tangerines, grapefruit, and tropical fruits.  Flavor of pine and grapefruit along with a solid malt backbone.  Some bitterness but also slightly sweet.  The oak from the dry-hop are detectable, but the high alcohol is absolutely not.  Light bitterness in the finish.  Altogether this DIPA is extraordinarily balanced and light without the often over-the-top bitterness/stickiness of others in this style.  Yet another reason that San Diego is awesome.

On tap at Stone Bistro.  Clear dark gold pour, sticky white head, with nice lacing.  Citrus, grapefruit, tropical fruit, pine, resinous hops, caramel malt, melon, and floral notes.  A very juicy IIPA, lots of hops.

growler thanks to weibull (from BA).  Took a lot of trading firepower to obtain this bad boy.  Pours a clear, light-golden color with a nice white head.  Nose is wonderful grass, pine and mandarin oranges.  I could have smelled this all day.  Fortunately, I got a hold of this incredibly fresh.  Taste was great citrus and pine with caramel malt to offset.  Mouthfeel was creamy and smooth with a nice bitterness.  This reminded me of Pliny the Elder.  Very impressed with this.  Truly top-three  IIPA.

On tap at OBriens.  Rating 2000.  Color was a dark gold with a whitish head.  Aroma was great; citrus, pine, grapefruit and flowers.  Flavor was dangerously drinkable; cant believe its 11 percent.  Nuanced and hoppy, the flavor is a great blend of grapefruit, melon, flowers, and citrus.  Palate was nice, almost creamy.  Top notch beer.

UPDATED: SEP 13, 2010 I finally got my hands on this beer. From K&L in Redwood City. $15 ouch!!! The first thing that hits you is the insanely fresh hop aroma. You can smell and taste the copious amounts of fresh hops in this beer. No wonder its so expensive. First it knocks you back and makes you question weather you really like hoppy beers this much.  The real fresh hop flavor that this beer has is unparalleled. Some big hop beers are so phony because they use hop resins. As a serious hop head I really advise you to try this beer if your like me.  Its a hardcore hop assault and still drinkable. Worthy of the Alpha King award. A special experience and a true hop fest beer!!!!!!    Unbelievable hop freshness!!!

From Growler. poured into duvel tulip. Pours a bright orange with average white head. Aroma. wow! alot going on here.  Tons of floral and tropical flavors mango, Peach, pinapple and pine hops.
Flavor is a mix of tangerine and peach with a nice warming feel. Alcohol is present, but not overbearing,  The more it warms the more noticable it becomes. Very easy drinker. It will hit you after a few glasses.
UPDATED: JUL 20, 2009 Thanks to Rciesla for sharing. This IIPA although at 11 percent alcohol ,didnt know at the time, is very smooth and had little after bite. Very grass flavor very good beer.

Got to partake in a growler, courtesy of Adrian. Pours a golden corn coloured yellow with a foamy white head. Overwhelming aroma of floral hops, pine and citrus. Bitter taste of floral hops, citrus, and pine. Has a perfumy taste.
Growler thanks to BMan1113VR. Orange in color with a decent sized white head. Aroma is of pine, grass, hops, hay and caramel. Taste is rich in caramel with loads of hops, grass and spruce.

Growler pour courtesy of the BMan11113VR, many thanks ! Light amber color with a white head. Grapefruit citrusy aromas with flowers and ganja smoke.  Smooth medium body.  Huge floral and spruce sap hop flavors on a hefty sweet caramel malt base. Alcohol is well hidden. Great IPA.
user_location: Same Trailer, Different Park, Louisiana, USA

text: Growler, courtesy tpd975. Golden copper pour, big white head and thick lacing. Big pine in the nose, citrus, tons of vanilla and spices, some heat. Works well. Huge pine flavors, citrus and tropical notes, some dry grain and oily hoppiness creates a very full and yummy body. Drinkable as hell, very delicious. Right up there with the best of the imperial IPAs.

Nose was very sweet with vanilla and hoppy citrusness. 
Mouthfeel is not too thin, slightly sweet and sticky with really strong caramel flavor, big bitter hoppiness, very back and forth flavor profile.

Growler thanks to bman1113vr.  Clear look, golden in color, decent off whit head.  The smell is grapefuirts, hops, citrus, florals, caramel, and hops.  Nice.  The taste is malts, caramel, hop,s florals, citrus, and goodness.

Hand bottle generously given to me by my friend mreusch. It pours a pretty, nearly-clear amber with a fluffy white head that diminishes leaving behind cascading lace. This beer features an amazing hop nose without smacking you in the face: citric, floral, perfumy and lightly resinous hop notes are supported by candy sugar and sweet light caramel malt notes. Very nice. Medium-bodied with soft carbonation and a solid tongue-squeezing bitterness that lingers on the back sides of the tongue long after you swallow. There is also a touch of alcohol warmth at the finish. Amazingly subtle and well-integrated up-front: notes of citric and floral hops dance in-step with sweet caramel malt. Pleasantly bitter with a touch of alcohol thrown into the mix, this is an IIPA that doesnt try to hide what it is or feel the need bully its way past your taste buds to get your attention. One of the most refined examples of the style that Ive sampled, this is the Cary Grant of IIPAs. Thanks a million for the bottle of this amazing beer, Matt.

From a growler.  Clear orange with a smooth ivory head.  Leaves lacy veils.  Nose is pine, chamomile, sweet tea and toffee.  Wow, this is a beefy DIPA.  Chewy, mouth coating with buzzy carb.  Seems to have held up well even after multiple pours.  Taste is grapefruit, vanilla caramel, juniper and black pepper.  As it warms notes of melon, mango and brown sugar.  Lots of hops but still well balanced and very drinkable.  Excellent.

On tap at the brewery. Pours a clear amber with a white ring. Very bitter aroma, quite herbal, with hops, pine, and a lot of grass. Intense taste, very herbal, a lot of dill and grass, with pine hops. Hides the alcohol well. Lingering huge bitterness. Big and bold.

(Growler, courtesy of Bman1113vr)  Pours a clear golden body with a moderate white head.  Aroma of mango, pineapple, orange, florals, grapefruit, and tangerine.  Flavor of hops (mango, citrus, earth) and caramel malt with a dry, bitter finish.

growler thanks to bman1113vr.  poured a light gold with a whit head.  aroma of pine, sweetness, and a hot pepper type of spice.  flavor was sweet and pine resin.  light-medium body and low carbonation.  great stuff.

Generously shared by mreusch by way of alohaC, I believe.  Pour is clear golden with a smallish white head that leaves behind nice sticky lacing. Aroma of immediate and big resin, citrus, and spicy hops.  Only a hint of bitterness, just fresh hop goodness.  Nice  grainy maltiness is there as well, but certainly behind that crazy fresh hop blast. Taste is the resin hoppiness, the citrus, though still decently balanced with a strong bready maltiness.  Palate is medium to full, very dry, with not much sweetness. What was there was citrus fruit, and quite fresh.  Really no apparent alcohol, which is amazing.  Nice mouth coating - this is my kind of DIPA.  Thanks for sharing this rarity Matt!

UPDATED: NOV 4, 2009 Re rated on may 24th on tap at downtown johnny browns. Much better on tap than on cask in my opinion. Great lacing and tons of citrus and oak on the nose. Flavor was nice and oaky with some hop bitterness.


On hand pump @ Toronado S.D.  Pours a hazy burnt orange color with a fluffy 2 finger off white head, not much lacing.  Nose was very fruity with citrus, pine and sweet malt.  Very low bitterness and very smooth, very balanced.  Brew barley tastes like a Double, can taste about 7% worth of booze.  Not really what I was expecting, will try again on draft instead of cask next time.

Growler because tpd975 is the man.  Pours yellow gold with a white head.  Nose is all manner of hops- apricot, peach, pine, and tart citrus.  Flavor is apricot, loquat, sugar, malt, caramel, and peach.  I love it when Double IPAs are so hoppy that they take on flavor like apricot and peach.  Lots of similarities to PTY.  Medium to full-bodied and lingering piney apricot finish.  Excellent beer.
Thanks to Beerlando.  Golden body.  with a white head.  Incredible amounts of citrusy hops and pine.  Strong alcohol in this one.  Very tasty.

Growler kindly shared by Beerlando. Extraordinary. Pour gold, white head, nice lacing. Huge mango and pine hops all over the place. West Coast all the way. Nose is huge, alcohol is superbly hidden. This is insanely drinkable. I could have killed a growler of this myself. The malt balance is fantastic, because it carries the immense hoppiness so unobtrusively. Full, lush mouthfeel. Nice mildly drying, pine-hop finish. Well-done!

growler courtesy of tpd975. Thanks Greg for this ultimate hop bag.
Never thought I would enjoy a DIPA that much.
Pours golden, white head.
Aroma, like opening a bag of fresh grass/pine, loaded with amazing scent and hops.
Taste, lots of grass, pine hops, some spices, light apricot/peach fruit notes, remains highly smooth on the palate.
This is one fine brewed beer.

Growler courtesy of tpd975. Pours a real hazy yellow, thick white head. Smells like a citrus pine forest. Yay Hops! Nose reminds me of pliny. Tastes citrusy, sweet caramel malts. Oily, full mouthfeel. A real treat!

Growler courtesy of tpd975. Pours a hazy golden yellow color with a thin white head. Aroma is sweet and floral with notes of pine, citrus, grapefruit, honey, caramel, light notes of candy sugar, pineapple, and tropical fruits. Flavor is sweet and floral with notes of pine, grass, citrus, grapefruit, honey, candy sweetness, dried apricots. Generally medium body with a pleasing hoppy finish.

nuked rating retry #2.  Gold pour with a nice sized head.  Aroma is heavy citrus and resin hops.  Flavor had quite a bit of exotic island fruit.  Not quite as bone dry as expected,  but very bitter to pack it up.  Very delicious.

Growler, courtesy of Snojerk321. Unfortunately, a bit spilled out and it lost some of the carbonation, but its still crazy good (kinda like a casked version). Pours a nice gold with a fizzy soap bubble head. Nose of citrus, dust, a touch of resin and some pineapple. I pick up some caramel as well. Taste follows suit, a lot sweeter than expected, given that its from SoCal. I pick up some vanilla along with the citrus and caramel. Alcohol very well hidden. This is a pretty damn tasty IIPA, not at the top, but still damn tasty.

UPDATED: APR 1, 2010 Growler, courtesy beerlando. Pours a bright golden orange color with a small, foamy off white head that leaves sudsy patches of lacing behind. The aroma is big and nice of huge citrus hops and pine resin on top of the sweet and toasted caramel malt base. A lot of sweet caramel comes through almost like candy. The flavor follows with the bitter orange and grapefruit hops to go with a big dose of pine resin. The hops are balanced nicely by the big, sweet caramel malt yet still plenty of bitterness on the backend. Medium-full bodied and very smooth and almost chewy on the mouthfeel. The finish is long and bittersweet from all the hops. This is a huge double ipa and a tasty one at that.

Growler courtesy of tpd975. Pours a slightly hazy pale golden with a one finger white head that leaves good lacing. Aroma is like sticking your head into a bag of the best hops and reefer in the world with notes of apricot, orange, and lemon with a solid dose of pine. Taste is more hops and reefer. Medium mouthfeel with an insaine amount of bitterness and smooth as hell alcohol. This beer is in no way balanced but I love hops and thats what this beer is all about. A damn fine brew.

Growler.  Pours a hazy, glowing, golden-orange color.  A thick, frothy, off-white head is lasting, and leaves dense, sticky patches of cloud like lacing behind.  Right up front, the nose shows a powerful blast of citrus blossom hops, followed by sticky pine resin and hints of cannabis.  The underlying malt base is bold in its own right, buttered toffee and hints of toast coming to mind.  Flavors continue the trend, strikingly bitter with grapefruit, orange, and pine hops, yet sufficiently balanced with ample, sweet toffee malts.  Big, thick, and smooth, the palate skirts the edge of being syrupy, but ultimately settles on the substantial, non-cloying side of things.  This is a massive, crushing IIPA, bold in every sense of the word, and I love it.
Nice upfront bitterness. Taste is pine and cat pee. Very bitter end and lingers a lot with an earthy bitterness.

Thanks to Beerlando for hooking up this growler. Pours a clear golden copper. Caramel malt, citrusy pine hops. Hops are very overpowering, just huge! Taste is big and bitter citrus pine hops with a huge malt profile, but I think the hops still win in this. This is just monster hoppy beer.

Growler courtesy of JessetheHutt shared with the usual suspects at the Brick Store.

Pours a deep clear amber with a short-lived off-white head that leaves bits of lacing on the way down.

The aroma is massive with a big, deep resinous pine hop smell that is almost more sweet than bitter combined with the tropical fruit presence of oranges and grapefruits.

The taste is spectacular with the massive pine hop bitterness up front that just hangs onto the palate as the bready malt backbone and citrus hops all pile on.  I also seem to get an interesting spiciness that tingles the palate between sips...tough to identify.  This is a seriously complex beer. 

The mouthfeel is certainly on the fuller side of things with enough soft carbonation to carry all of the flavors that assault the palate.  The flavors just stick to the tongue and build up after each sip.

This is one of the biggest DIPAs Ive ever tasted.  Im not sure Ive ever gotten so many different flavors in a beer of this style and Im seriously impressed by this one.  Pure Hoppiness is good, but this just blew me away.  World class.

Shared by Rciesla.  Thanks!  Pours a very clear very light golden (perhaps a SRM or 2 lighter than even Pliney?)- low carbonation and a film for a head.  Aroma is very piney and powerfully loaded with resinous hops- almost a nice dank weed hop component as well which is nice.  Flavor is tacky with tons of resinous hops, citrus, some grapefruit and lots of pine sap with some nice tropical fruitiness to liven it up a bit.  Great smooth and slight resinous hop bite throughout and at the end of the palate.  Pretty good overall.  This may be better than the previous times I have had it, but I was probably drunk the other times.
Bronze color. Sweet caramel and citrus hops.  The caramel is almost dominating over the strong hoppiness.  Very good, very hoppy, very sweet.

growler, thanks to bman1113vr, I had taken this off my wants list not expecting to find it, lighter orange color, skim foam, typical aroma of pine, pineapple, flavor however is more lavender , buttery, hoppy finish, warmed up nicely

Growler thanks to bman1113vr. Gold pour with a quickly receding head. Amazing amount of floral hops on the nice, a nice earthiness and some butter. Taste was hops, butter, mango and other fruits. Delicious ber!

Big thanks to stefanje for trading this to me for my tasting. Pours with a small white head with great lace and a clear golden body. Aroma is hoppy with exotic fruits, melon and citrus. Taste is alcohol, exotic fruit hops, caramel, vanilla, and a light earthiness. Amazingly well balanced. Light carbonation and a slightly creamy mouthfeel.


Everyone loved this...The growler was gone almost instantly.

growler, pours hazy golden with white head. nose of piney, citrus, grapefruit, earthy hop notes, flavors are sweet citrus, melon, tropical fruit, grapefrut notes with a dry very slightly woody earthy finish. lively fresh mouth feel. tastes wonderful. long clean, flavorful finish. wonderful brew!

GROWLer thanks to an unnamed trader.  Pours  golden bronze body with a nice pine and citrus aroma.  Tropical fruits and fresh cut grass with a doughy body and a spicy hop resin finish.  The etoh comes across more like a sweet piney pineapple.  An awesome imperial IPA but... its still no pliny.

UPDATED: APR 12, 2009 growler from hophead22.  thank you sir for i have been trying to try this for the longest time.....pours a moderately transparent golden orange brown with a half-finger white soapy head.... awesome aroma of dank green hops as well as lots of aromatic tropical fruit and pineapple....flavors carry through with crazy sweet tropical hops, maybe some honey added for some sweetness, just a touch of bitterness in the finish.  remarkably smooth and drinkable. i

I cant thank Jon enough for sending this my way (Ive tried many a time to trade for it).  Poured light-to-moderate peachy-golden with a swirly cap of eggshell head.  The aroma opened with copious amounts of pineapple, fresh grassy, and resiny pine hoppage over a pale and lightly bready base.. warm hop candy that I lost about 15 minutes of my evening smelling.  The flavor opened with zesty pineapple and piney bitterness amplified by warmth.. pineapple and grapefruit meat joined caramel and almost bourbonny sugars (this must be from the oak addition) at the core.. finished with great balance between the resiny hops and sweetness.  Heavier-bodied on the palate with just enough carbonation to move it well across the palate.. spicy and warm, but the ABV was very well hidden.. loved that the finish stuck for so long.  Fantastic!

Growler with a huge thanks to alohaC for the chance to finally try this beauty!  Pours a clear golden with a moderate foamy white cap.  Aroma is a wonderful blend, with citrus, grass, pine, floral, grapefruit, and even light spice and tropical fruits in the mix.  Flavor is equally stellar, with more of the same, and the floral and tropical fruits coming out a little more.  A nice lasting finish, and well balanced against a gentle caramel malt background with even a hint of vanilla.  This is a very well done DIPA, and easily on par with some of the best in the style.  Thanks again Christian, I definitely owe you one!

Growler thanks to hophead22! Poured a nice golden color with nice long lasting white head. Aroma is hops and more hops. Taste is grass hops, floral hops, little malt, and more pine hops. Has a nice bitter finish and very easy to drink. Really nice brew.

Growler shared by wolf... Nice light golden orange color, good head. Awesome aroma of hops as soon as its poured. Lots of pine and grass on the nose. Taste is the same, lots of pine, lots of grass and citrus hops. Basically hoppy and bitter.  Well balanced. Really smooth and easy to drink. Not a trace of the 11 percent. Overall a great beer. Thanks to wolf and hophead22!

Great aroma.  Nice rich complex hops, pine, spice, floral and only a touch tropical.  Great upfront aroma and flavors.  Not as rich and viscious as I usually enjoy.  Mid is nice but starts to fade and the finish is short.  Maybe the 10+ alc thins and cuts this down too early.  It is pretty darn good, wish this was in bottle.

Growler. Thanks JV for picking this up for me! Pours a clear golden with a medium white head. Nose if strong pine resins, and a nice floral bouquet. Flavors go from grapefruit to grapefruit zest. Sugary at times. Pine resins take over at times too. Mouth is uber bitter with a long finish. Alcohol sneaks up at the beginning then shows its face more. Great beer, complex hop characters with an excellent malt backing.

Growler shared with friends at Hangar 24 thanks to Hophead22.  Pours a clear orange color with a white head.  Aroma is fantastic with a touch of citrus but more pine, some pineapple and honeysuckle sweetness.  Flavor is pretty much all the same.  The first thing I noticed was the coconut pina colada kind of flavor, probably due to the vanilla from the oak chips combined with the pineapple.  Full mouthfeel a little spritzy carbonation.

Growler from the brewery. Dark yellow pour, very clear with a nice white head and lots of lacing. Lots of pine with the slightest bit of sweetness. Very smooth, a good amount of maltiness to go with the hops and some alcohol warmth in the finish. This was very good.
user_location: Redlands, by way of Wisconsin,, California, USA

text:
A- Clear light orange hue, thin lacing of white foam, spotty lacing
S- Bouquet of citrus and pine hops, dark fruits and molasses
T- Taste starts with smooth pine and grapefruit hop wave, transitions to floral, earthy and grassy hops, a nice cascade of hop flavors
M- Medium-bodied, oily resin texture coats mouth, mild carbonation
D- This embodies complexity and layering within a bold DIPA, it is delicious from start to finish, the alcohol is totally masked which is a feat at 10%, this was an absolute joy to have on cask and one of my new faves

On tap at stone bistro

Pours a nice orange with a small white head. Aroma of hops, malt, pine and malt. Flavor is oily resinous hops, malt, pine with a nice bitter finish. Seemed a little off to me, but I did drink this right after I had a hop suey so anything I had after that may have had higher than normal expectations. Decent IPA, but I had higher expectations for this one.

8-28-08 growler shared by hopsleeroy - you rock! 
Bright glowing orange with a thin white head.  Smell is floral, minty, basil, and fruity.  Nice mouthfeel and body.  Great overall flavor that is perfectly hopped and that has this cold minty aspect and great fruity hop finish.  Very refreshing and very flavorful and enjoyable.

UPDATED: MAY 6, 2009 Growler shared by hopsleeroy.  Thanks a ton dude!
Pours a clear orang color with a light white head.  SMell is sweet and fruity, juicy hops and very herbacious with some basil and mint.  Very fresh smelling and quite nice and unique.  Taste is hoppy, fruity and very mild bitterness, but with huge hoppy unique flavors of mint and basil like hops.  Incredibly easy to drink, and no sign of the 10.5% ABV at all.  One of the better beers Ive ever had.  Awesome.

UPDATED: JUL 28, 2009 Growler thanks to hopsleeroy on BA.  Thanks Lee!  Pours clearish golden with a white head that leaves plenty of sticky lacing.  Smell is huge perfume-like hop aroma like fresh hop cones, a slight herbaceous smell and some slight vanilla/oak.  Huge, sweet hoppy flavor. Fresh hops and pine cones all over the flavor.  Vanilla and dry oakiness as well.  So easy to drink this one, I could hardly tell it was 11%.  Basically it was like squeezing juice right out of the hops into my mouth.

(growler, thanks kmweaver) Small white head atop clear golden body.  Aroma is moderately sweet, mango, some passion fruit, pineapple, orange.  Taste is moderately sweet, grapefruit, mango, light caramel.  Sticky medium-full body.

Thanks to Ken for this one.  Clear gold color, a white head with good retention.  Aroma has lots of awesome spicy flowery hops, a slight citrus sweetness in the back, and pineapple.  flavor is not overly bitter, lots of tropical fruits, and a bit of an earthiness.

UPDATED: AUG 18, 2008 Growler, courtesy of wetherel.  Thanks, John!  Pours a clear, tarnished copper color; creamy, light tan head with great retention and textured lacing, coating the glass; very nice pour.  Loads of tropical fruits, oily tree fruit hoppiness, and no astringency in the aroma; passion fruits and lime; gorgeous nose.  Medium-to-full mouthfeel: loads of oily, sweet tropical fruits, passion fruit, lime, and dripped tree fruits; gorgeous, clear, resiny hop character; no astringency; my favorite type of IIPA.  Gorgeous, hop-forward and clearly expressed.  Lengthy finish: toasted malts, passion fruits, and tree fruits.

Courtesy of kmweaver. Clear light amber body with a medium white head. Big hoppy, citrus fruit nose with peach, grapefruit, tangerine, also lots of sugars as well. The favor is moderately sweet, lots of cotton candy, lots of citrus hops, heavy bitterness. Medium/full body is chewy with light carbonation.

Growler from Wetherel, thanks!! I have been wanting to try this for sometime now, glad I finally got the chance. Pours a clean, clear light orange color with medium sized white head. Aroma of citrus hops and light malt. The taste was a mixture of various citrus flavors: pine, peach,melon,and weed. The taste was the same as the aroma with a nice semi sweet malt backbone.  This is a dangerous drinking brew as there is virtually no alchol presence.Lip smacking bitter finish. Also, this beer left me with hop burps,so you know it was super hoppy.

Pours orange with thick white head.  Aroma is overpowering floral hops.  I could just pour a glass and smell the beer.  Then the first taste is huge citrus hops with  piney resin.  Pure hop juice.  Thick, creamy mouthfeel.  A hophead’s dream beer.  Very easy drinking for 10.5%.

On tap at O’Brien’s Pub in San Diego. Very dry and bitter... very bitter. To me, not  a great balance between the hops and malt, and not a very good hoppy flavor, either. Very sharp on the palate and just not very enjoyable to drink. Too much carbonation. Too bad I got a pint, wish I only got a 10oz.

This was delicious, absolutely no way around it.  One of the best DIPAs I have ever tried.  Pours a hazy orange coloring, with that beautiful unfiltered look, and just reeks ( In a wonderful way) of pure hop juice.  Has that skunky resin nose, with lots of citrus fruits running the gamut.  Nice acidity and bitterness does a number on your palate, almost stings a bit, but the alcohol is really well masked.  Loads of fruit and an unbalanced malt background, but at this point you are not thinking about that and enjoying the hop overload.

A top of the line DIPA and a welcomed sight at our last tasting. Brought to us in a growler that was just poured a day or two earlier. Its a pleasure to enjoy a beer like this because it reminds you how good a DIPA can be. So many are passed off as this style and they just simply arent, no matter how good intentions there were to create one. Not only did Alpine succeed, they succeeded on a high level. 

The beer poured out of the growler a beautiful orange color, a creamy one-finger thick head with a complex hop attack of tropical fruits, pine resin, citrus peel and marijuana. Full bodied, creamy mouthfeel..no harshness at all. Flavors just explode with hoppy goodness. Its really not for the faint of heart. Juicy tropical fruits combined with the piney power of the hop and the resiny goodness that comes from it just really does cartwheels on the tongue. Theres a good bit of sweetness to counter the bitterness in this beer, but make no mistake...the hops are the star of this show and they should be. Highly recommended and a pleasure to drink.

Hazy straw colour.  Deep rich citrus, wood with light tropical fruit.  Such monster hops.  Astringent, extreme hops on the palate.  Bone dry.  Unbalanced, this pushes past my limits but Im sure theres an audience for bitter cantaloupe juice.
UPDATED: JAN 17, 2009 Growler from seaoflament (Thanks Carlos!) Really liked this one, from the caramel smooth and floral hoppiness in both nose and flavor.

On tap at Liars club, Alpine. Pours a very hazy amber wit a small white head and lacings. Bitter with lots of grapefruity hops aromas... and then some. Also some alcohol notes. Very bitter finish. X-treme on the hops... kind of one sided though.

growler shared by I forget who in line at the port anniversary party....great nose of grapefruity and piney hops and the flavor is much the same with the great interplay with the malts perfect balance...just a tad bit below pliney inmy opinion .....damn good job though pat!

Thanks to Josh for sharing this growler!  Pours a lightly hazy golden amber with a medium bubbly off white head.  Aroma of pine resin, caramel malt, toasted notes, grapefruit,  light oak, orange...nice a hoppy with a great malt balance.  Flavor of  tea, pine, dry hopped grassy notes, grapefruit, citrus, oak, caramel and some toffee.

Growler from Padrefan98, big thanks for this unexpected gift Jon. Pours a clear deep orangey copper with a large fluffy white head. Aroma is pure heaven. Tons of fresh hops balanced with the perfect touch of malt sweetness. I swear I could sit here and smell this all day long. Medium bodied that is slightly dry and finishes bitter but not overly bitter for the giant hop aroma. Flavor is full of fresh citrus hops, grapefruit rind, cereal, grain, and caramel and help balance this one out. I wish a little more of the sweetness from the aroma followed inot the flavor but still one fantastic beer.

Pours dark copper with a slight haze. A fullish rush of fine carbonation swells up a inch-plus head of off-white.
Ripped sheets of clingy foam, and a full coverage skim coat remains throughout.

Pungently hoppy with oak-laden malt undertones.
Grapefruit pith, candied bitter orange peel, pine resin, freshly turned earth, and oak bark. Alcohol is everpresent with each whiff. 

Sticky, sappy, chewy mouthfeel. Tongue- coating, and on the thick side of medium.

Bitter spruce sap, citrus oils, leafy hops, and juicy malt lead off the pallet. An oaky dryness steps forward along with warming alcohol. Lingering bitterness, ripe fruit, and forest floor are a mainstay for each sip.
A whallop of grapefruit, pine needles, and oaky malt.

Quite malty for an IIPA, and approaching barleywine territory, but stopping short.
A bit numbing in the nose and pallet, with the onslaught of hops and alcohol.

Similar to Hopsickle, but more malty, and the oaking adds some nice depth, which rounds out the brew as well.


Big ups to doubleo for hooking me up!
Orange amber pour, 1 finger white head.  Smells of grassy bitter hops.  Taste citrus then honeydew the bitter.  Thank you again pepsican.

Draught  Nearly no (yellow) head; hazy orange-ochre beer. Exploding, but very fine mandarine/tangerine hops, breaking out the glass - well, cup. Not overly bitter, but very hoppy (surprise, surprise), bit metallic and again marked tangerine/kumquat flavours. Quite oily MF, just a tad too thick & alcoholy to be refreshing, but still... Deeply impressed with this. Explosive overhoppiness, citrus bittering - exactly what it is NOT. Its actually very inviting.

On tap at Obriens. Golden murky amber with a thin white head. Enticing lemon, banana, citrus aromas. Smooth and slightly syrupy on your palate. Great bitter hops and perfect light malt. Sweetness hides any alcohol . Pine like finish! Dangerous indeed. Awesome. Beer!!

A well carbonated pour from the growler easily produces a three-finger thick, creamy textured, light tan colored crown of froth.  The beer is a lightly orange tinged, full amber color that shows a lightly hop-hazed, orange-copper hue when held up to the light.  The aroma is very sticky with hop notes; candied grapefruit, huge lychee, apricot & other tropical fruit notes are quite noticeable even while pouring this brew.  A focused sampling of the aroma gets aromatic notes that lean much more towards the herbal / pine  side of the spectrum.  Though the beer still smells of sticky, sugar preserved hop buds.  The sharper side of the hop produces notes of grass, pine sap, some slight chive notes, a huge hemp oil contribution.  It is interesting that this was so intensely fruity smelling as I was pouring it, but that a focused inspection of the aroma is much more dominated by concentrated herbal & essential oil components.

Sweet and thick tasting with a ton of residual malt sugars, these are not by any means overwhelming though as this has a huge hop character that easily offsets the malt; in fact the residual malt sugars are not even overly noticeable because of all the hop character.  Sharply bitter, with lots of green, astringent hop notes and a finish that tastes like what I would imagine chewing on a fat, juicy, marijuana bud (though there is lots of malt to keep this from becoming over-bearing).  Up front and through to the middle some nice, underlying citrus & tropical fruit flavors are found; these contribute flavors of lychee, candied ruby-red-grapefruit, orange-marmalade and peach concentrate.  This is clearly dominated by the greener hop flavors; in addition to the piquantly expressive hemp-oil flavor there are notes of chives, mentholated pine, lots of herbal turpenes (rosemary, garlic chive and a touch of sage oil).  Thick and chewy, this is approaching a Barleywine in heft, it just retains enough lightness to retain the IPA allusions though.  The plethora of hop character also keeps this from every getting sticky or cloying.  The malt character is clearly a supporting character, really not noticeable on its own, but it plays a significant role in carrying the hop character.

My second pour of this beer reminds me how very well carbonated this beer is; visually it is quite apparent, but the beer is thick enough that it is not as noticeable in the flavor as one might think, though it does add a certain prickle / lightness to the beer as it flows across the tongue.  This beer doesnt seem to take to warming as much as some, the combination of hops and alcohol gets a bit harsh after a bit.

Big, powerful, overbearing, an exercise in self inflicted tongue flagellation, but is it good.  It most certainly is, but it is a bit too astringent & hemp-oil dominated for me.  There are times when I can enjoy a scathing, tongue scraping, astringently hoppy beer, but most times I like something a bit more drinkable.  Definitely a beer for the enthusiastic hop head.  I am not sure if I am getting more discriminating or if I am just getting burned out on over-the-top beers, but this is not nearly as enjoyable as I expected.  I really do enjoy excessive amounts of hops in a beer, but it has to have a drinkability and finesse that this beer just doesnt quite have.  Still this is a good beer, though it is one I really only want a 12 oz serving of  (luckily I could share my growler, because there was no way I would finish it on my own).

Growler via WeeHeavySD.  Pours a clear golden orange with a large beige head.  Lots of lacing on the glass.  Aroma of freshly squeezed tangerine, floral hops and pine.  Taste is perfumy with notes of tangerine, pine and floral hops.  Excellent !!!

On-tap at the brewery and at Liars Club today. Pours cloudy orange with a sticky, off-white head, good lace. Smells earthy hoppy, very hoppy and grassy, with some grapefruit. Tastes of big, resiny, oily hoppiness. Lots of grassy flavor as well. Body is thick but not syrupy, good carbonation. As good as Hopsickle? I dont know about that.

UPDATED: OCT 15, 2008 Growler from Brewery. Pours a thick, slightly hazy dark copper color. Aroma is a little sweet with a big skunky hop bitterness. Some grapefruit and pine is noticeable. Big citrus peel bitterness. Medium carbonation. A little sweetness and some malts. Quite bitter yet remains fairly smooth on the palate. Dry bitter hop finish. Alcohol is well hidden. Quite easy to drink for its strength.

Poured from the bottom of a growler that I picked up at the brewery today; beautiful crystal clear amber-orange color, a small but lasting off white head, pretty impressive for the last glass in the growler.  Hoppy, piney, fruity and slightly sweet smell, some grapefruit and orange, maybe even pineapple,  Big, bad hop bitterness, nice caramel maltiness, very full and soft palate, a warmth from the alcohol, almost a barley wine character.  Seems strange to say, but its pretty mellow for a big hop bomb - and I mean that as a compliment.

UPDATED: JUL 7, 2009 Draught at Hollister Brewing Company.   Dark gold with a sticky white head that laces.   The aroma is citrus and flowery hops; not to over the top.   The flavor has a good amount of sweet but clean malts.   The hops are plentiful, but not overly bitter.   Very flavorful with an herbal, woody quality.   The alcohol is very well hidden.   Balance is almost perfect.   Palate is medium and smooth.   The strength truly is dangerous.   Tastes like a well balanced and flavorful IPA.   I would never guess that is is as strong as it is.   Very drinkable. (4)

Rerate: growler from the brewery on release day last friday, consumed that night with the two buddies that I drove out there with.   This is a glorious beer.   Having this fresh on release day couldnt have hurt, but this ws just stunning stuff, with the oak and tropical fruity hops working perfectly together in the aroma, and the flavor balancing sweetness and bitterness just so to hide the ridiculous 11.25% abv that this batch came out to.   You would never guess that this beer is that strong, but the flavor is a pleasurable sensory overload.   Alpine is quickly becoming one of my favorite breweries.
on tap-pours a patchy light tan head and gold color.  Aroma is simcoe citrus hops.  Taste is alcohol, simcoe citrus hops, some medium malt.  Dry, raw, sipping.  Occasional.

Growler: Courtesy of Ibrew2or3 Big thanks for this one. Pours a golden amber with frothy head with lots of lacing as go through my snifter.Smell is of Grapefruit, lots of fruity esters, and some pepper.Taste is hops,citrus, and a hint of mint.Palate is a thin but crushing this is one hoppy beer one of the best i have had. Another big thank to Ibrew2or3

UPDATED: JAN 5, 2010 Rererate.  22oz bottle, no date (late 2009 bottling) from South Bay in SD.  Im not gonna bother with the look or body if I dont need to.  Big tropical fruit citrus pine nose with light clean caramel.  Some dry hopping grassiness/tastiness noted.  If I try, I get a little clean oak.  The new bottling seems to be much tastier and smellier than my previous samplings, so now Ill put it at a 4.3 now.  Rerate.  22oz bottle from wetherel, thanks John!  Clear orange with a 1/2 finger light beige head, fading to a thick ring and film before too long.  Aroma is full of fruit--pineapple and citrus the strongest--with plenty of piny hops as well.  Sweet caramel, cotton candy and light grass make up the rest of the aroma.  Flavor seems to be a bit subdued due to the intense bitterness of the beer.  This doesnt make sense, but its all I can figure out at this point.  I cant say that I can pick out any oak chips anywhere.  Anyways, the caramel and cotton candy sweetness are a good deal stronger in the flavor, but still cant undo what has been done with the hops. Bone dry finish.  Full body with low carbonation.  Even though they are both fruity, this takes on a completely different road compared to something like Dreadnaught.  Not bad--merely different.  I dont really like the intensity of the cotton candy though.  

Old Rating Follows. Notes from Dark Lord Day 07.  Clear honey golden with a small white head, decent retention.  Aroma of orange, pine, and grapefruity hops up front with some buttery malts, light grain and pale malts in the background.  Just a hint of Alcohol.  The flavor was much the same with a little more astringency and butter, alcohol still not too strong, with a hint of paper.  Semidry finish.  Medium body with low carbonation.  Not too bad, but it definitely wasnt amazing.  Ive actually got a 22oz bottle from wetherel that will be opened within the hour, so well see how a fresher sample fairs.  7-4-7-3-14--3.5
user_location: Ocean Beach, San Diego, California, USA

text: UPDATED: MAR 25, 2009 Growler from brewery pours gold with nice lasting off white head and sheet lacing. The aroma is full of grapefruit and tangelo to spice hops along with some pine hops in there as well. There is a backbone of malty sweetness in the nose too. The taste is thick and rich and viscous with grapefruit, tangelo and orange peel hop flavor and hop bitterness. Excellent mix of fresh tasty hops that grows more and more bitter into the finish. A malty sweetness tries to be heard over the torrent of hop notes but never really gets it done. Absolutely delicious brew, Wow!

UPDATED: JAN 1, 2008 Courtesy of Styles
Bottle:  Big citrus hops, pineapple, and tropical fruit aroma.  Transparent amber with a small white head that leaves behind spotty lacing. Lots of fruitiness up front with pineapple and hints of tropical fruits.  Very faint caramel in the background.   Nice balanced citrus hoppy finish.  Big fresh hoppiness throughout.  Medium bodied with a soft mouhfeel.

On tap @ PPSAF.  Deep orange in color with a nice fluffy off white head. Citrusy hoppy aroma. Pine, earthy grassy notes. Malty hoppy flavor. Caramel toffee notes. Full bodied. Well balanced. Nice beer.

2007 PP SAF. Poured golden. Strong pine and citrus aroma. Flavor is strong bitterness with some sweet fruity malt that accompanies the big pine bitterness. Alcohol is masked. Finishes with an incredible lingering dryness.

2007 PP SAF: Golden hue with nice frothy head and spotty lace. The aroma has notes of juicy fruit gum and pineapple, grassy and herbal, clove and pepper, and a hint of band-aid. The taste starts with a sharp fruity acidity and bitter overtones balanced slightly by biscuity malts. Spicy tones upon the finish. The mouth feel is lively and refreshing with a dry finish. The alcohol is dangerously well hidden. A really nice brew I would have again.

sweet tangerine if fresher and sweetner than ever,
